reference_answer:
The painting located on the east wall of the chapel of St Faith in the south transept holds significant historical and artistic value. This artwork depicts St. Faith holding a grid-iron, which is emblematic of her martyrdom. According to tradition, St. Faith was martyred by being roasted to death on a grid-iron, making this element central to understanding both the subject matter and symbolic meaning of the painting.

The approximate date of creation for this painting is between 1290 and 1310. This period places it in the late medieval era, a time characterized by rich religious art that often focused on themes of martyrdom and sanctity. The depiction of St. Faith not only serves as an artistic representation but also functions as a devotional image intended to inspire faith and reverence among viewers.

The painting's location within the chapel of St Faith, which was built around 1250 as the vestry for the abbey’s monks, further underscores its importance. As part of the religious setting, it would have been an integral component of the spiritual life at the abbey, reinforcing the narrative and virtues associated with St. Faith.

Overall, this painting is significant not only for its artistic merit but also for its role in conveying religious stories and values during a time when such imagery was pivotal to monastic education and devotion.

query: Describe the architectural style and unique features of the ceiling in the Henry VII Chapel, including who was likely responsible for its design.
reference_contexts:
['=== Henry VII Chapel ===

The Henry VII Lady Chapel, also known simply as the Henry VII Chapel, is a large lady chapel at the far eastern end of the abbey which was paid for by the will of King Henry VII. The chapel, built in late Perpendicular Gothic style, inspired English poet John Leland to call it the orbis miraculum (the wonder of the world). The tombs of several monarchs, including Edward V, Henry VII, Edward VI, Mary I, Elizabeth I, James I, Charles II, George II and Mary, Queen of Scots, are in the chapel.
It is noted for its pendant- and fan vault-style ceiling, probably designed by William Vertue, which writer Washington Irving said was "achieved with the wonderful minuteness and airy security of a cobweb". The ceiling is not a true fan vault, but a groin vault disguised as a fan vault. The interior walls are densely decorated with carvings, including 95 statues of saints. Many statues of saints in England were destroyed in the 17th century, so these are rare survivors. Like much of the rest of the medieval building, they would originally have been painted and gilded. From outside, The chapel walls are supported from outside by flying buttresses, each in the form of a polygonal tower topped with a cupola. At the centre of the chapel is the tomb of Henry VII and his wife, Elizabeth of York, which was sculpted by Pietro Torrigiano (who fled to England from Italy after breaking Michaelangelo's nose in a fight).
The chapel has sub-chapels radiating from the main structure. One, to the north, contains the tombs of Mary I and Elizabeth I; both coffins are in Elizabeth's monument. Another, to the south, contains the tomb of Mary, Queen of Scots. Both monuments were commissioned by James I, Elizabeth's successor to the English throne and Mary's son. At the far eastern end is the RAF Chapel, with a stained-glass window dedicated to those who died in the 1940 Battle of Britain. The RAF Chapel was the original burial site of Oliver Cromwell in 1658. Cromwell was disinterred in 1661, after the Stuart Restoration, when his body was hanged in chains on the gallows at Tyburn.
The chapel has been the mother church of the Order of the Bath since 1725, and the banners of its members hang above the stalls. The stalls retain their medieval misericords: small ledges for monks to perch on during services, often decorated with varied and humorous carvings.


=== Monastic buildings ===

Many rooms used by the monks have been repurposed. The dormitory became a library and a school room, and the monks' offices have been converted into houses for the clergy. The abbot had his own lodgings, and ate separately from the rest of the monks. The lodgings, now used by the Dean of Westminster, are probably the oldest continuously occupied residence in London. They include the Jericho Parlour (covered in wooden linenfold panelling), the Jerusalem Chamber (commissioned in 1369), and a grand dining hall with a minstrels' gallery which is now used by Westminster School. The prior also had his own household, separate from the monks, on the site of present-day Ashburnham House in Little Dean's Yard (now also part of Westminster School).']
reference_answer:
The Henry VII Chapel is designed in the late Perpendicular Gothic style. One of its most distinctive architectural features is its pendant- and fan vault-style ceiling. This ceiling is particularly notable because it is not a true fan vault but rather a groin vault that has been disguised as a fan vault, creating an intricate and airy appearance. The design of this ceiling is attributed to William Vertue, who likely played a significant role in its creation.

The ceiling's craftsmanship is described by writer Washington Irving as being "achieved with the wonderful minuteness and airy security of a cobweb," highlighting its delicate yet robust construction. This feature exemplifies the advanced architectural techniques of the period and contributes to the chapel's reputation as an extraordinary example of Gothic architecture, earning it the title "orbis miraculum" or "wonder of the world" from English poet John Leland.

In addition to the ceiling, the chapel is supported externally by flying buttresses that take the form of polygonal towers topped with cupolas. These structural elements not only provide support but also add to the aesthetic grandeur of the building. Inside, the walls are richly decorated with carvings and statues of saints, many of which have survived from a time when similar artworks were destroyed in England during the 17th century. Originally, these would have been painted and gilded, adding further splendor to the chapel's interior.

query: Explain the historical significance of the RAF Chapel within the Henry VII Chapel, particularly focusing on its original purpose and any notable figures associated with it.
reference_contexts:
['=== Henry VII Chapel ===

reference_answer:
The RAF Chapel within the Henry VII Chapel holds significant historical importance due to its original role as a burial site for Oliver Cromwell in 1658. Cromwell was a key figure during the English Civil War, serving as Lord Protector of the Commonwealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland following the execution of King Charles I. His interment at Westminster Abbey marked an unusual event, given his Puritan beliefs which typically opposed elaborate burials.

However, after the Stuart Restoration in 1660, when the monarchy was restored under King Charles II, Cromwell's body was exhumed from the RAF Chapel and subjected to a posthumous execution. His remains were hanged at Tyburn, reflecting the intense political and religious tensions of the time.

The RAF Chapel itself is also notable for its stained-glass window dedicated to those who died in the 1940 Battle of Britain, linking it to more recent history and commemorating the bravery of Royal Air Force personnel during World War II. This dual historical significance underscores the chapel's role as a site of both political intrigue from the 17th century and national remembrance from the 20th century.

query: Discuss how the monastic buildings have been repurposed over time, specifically mentioning the current uses of the abbot's lodgings and the prior's household site.
reference_contexts:
['=== Henry VII Chapel ===

The Henry VII Lady Chapel, also known simply as the Henry VII Chapel, is a large lady chapel at the far eastern end of the abbey which was paid for by the will of King Henry VII. === Monastic buildings ===

Many rooms used by the monks have been repurposed. The dormitory became a library and a school room, and the monks' offices have been converted into houses for the clergy. The abbot had his own lodgings, and ate separately from the rest of the monks. The lodgings, now used by the Dean of Westminster, are probably the oldest continuously occupied residence in London. reference_answer:
The monastic buildings at Westminster Abbey have undergone significant transformations over time to accommodate new functions while preserving their historical significance. Many rooms that were originally used by monks have been repurposed for modern use.

1. **Abbot’s Lodgings**: The abbot's lodgings, which are now utilized by the Dean of Westminster, represent one of the oldest continuously occupied residences in London. These lodgings include several notable features such as:
   - The Jericho Parlour: This room is distinguished by its wooden linenfold panelling.
   - The Jerusalem Chamber: Commissioned in 1369, this chamber adds historical depth to the abbot's lodgings.
   - A grand dining hall with a minstrels' gallery: Originally used for communal meals and entertainment, it now serves Westminster School.

2. **Prior’s Household Site**: The site of the prior's household, which was separate from that of the monks, is located on what is now Ashburnham House in Little Dean's Yard. This area has been integrated into the facilities of Westminster School, reflecting its adaptation to contemporary educational needs.

These repurposed spaces illustrate how historical structures can be adapted for modern use while maintaining their cultural and architectural heritage.

query: Who designed the present high altar and screen at Westminster Abbey, and what notable artists contributed sculptures and mosaics to this design?
reference_contexts:
['== Artworks and treasures ==
The nave and transepts have sixteen crystal chandeliers made of hand-blown Waterford glass. Designed by A. B. Read and Stephen Dykes Bower, they were donated by the Guinness family in 1965 to commemorate the abbey's 900th anniversary. The choir stalls were designed by Edward Blore in 1848. Some stalls are assigned to high commissioners of countries in the Commonwealth of Nations.
Beyond the crossing to the west is the sacrarium, which contains the high altar. The abbey has the 13th-century Westminster Retable, thought to be the altarpiece from Henry III's 13th-century church and the earliest surviving English panel painting altatrpiece, in its collections. The present high altar and screen were designed by George Gilbert Scott between 1867 and 1873, with sculptures of Moses, St Peter, St Paul, and King David by H. H. Armistead, as well as a mosaic of the Last Supper by J. R. Clayton and Antonio Salviati.
The south transept contains wall paintings made c. 1300, which Richard Jenkyns calls "the grandest of their time remaining in England". Depicting Thomas the Apostle looking at Christ's wounds and St Christopher carrying the Christ Child, the paintings were discovered in 1934 behind two monuments. Fourteenth-century paintings are on the backs of the sedilia (seats used by priests on either side of the high altar). On the south side are three figures: Edward the Confessor, the angel Gabriel, and the Virgin Mary. On the north side are two kings (possibly Henry III and Edward I) surrounding a religious figure, possibly St Peter. They were walled off during the Commonwealth period by order of Parliament, and were later rediscovered.
Over the Great West Door are ten statues of 20th-century Christian martyrs of various denominations; the statues were sculpted by the abbey's craftsmen in 1998. Those commemorated are Maximilian Kolbe, Manche Masemola, Janani Luwum, Grand Duchess Elizabeth Feodorovna, Martin Luther King Jr., Óscar Romero, Dietrich Bonhoeffer, Esther John, Lucian Tapiedi, and Wang Zhiming.
From the chapter house is a doorway leading to the abbey's library, which was built as a dormitory for the monks and has been used as a library since the 16th century. The collection has about 16,000 volumes. Next to the library is the Muniment Room, where the abbey's historic archives are kept.


=== Cosmati pavement ===

At the crossing in front of Edward the Confessor's shrine and the main altar is the Cosmati pavement, a 700-year-old tile floor made of almost 30,000 pieces of coloured glass and stone. Measuring almost 25 feet square, coronations take place here.
The floor is named after the Cosmati family in Rome, who were known for such work. It was commissioned by Richard Ware, who travelled to Rome in 1258, when he became abbot, and returned with stone and artists. The porphyry used was originally quarried as far away as Egypt, and was presumably brought to Italy during the Roman Empire. It was surrounded by a Latin inscription in brass letters (since lost) identifying the artist as Odericus, probably referring to designer Pietro di Oderisio or his son. The inscription also predicted the end of the world 19,863 years after its creation. Unlike traditional mosaic work, the pieces were not cut to a uniform size but made using a technique known as opus sectile ("cut work"). It is unique among Cosmati floors in Europe for the use of dark Purbeck-marble trays, forming bold borders, instead of the more typical white marble. The pavement influenced later floor treatments at St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle, and Canterbury Cathedral.
Geometric designs, such as those in the pavement, were thought to help the abbey's monks with contemplation, and conveyed medieval Christian ideas on the nature of the universe that could not easily be put into words. Much of the design relies on the geometric doubling of the square, considered a trade secret by stonemasons. The four-sided squares, four-fold symmetry, and the four inner roundels of the design represent the four elements of classical philosophy, with the central roundel representing the unformed state of the universe at its creation. Each inner roundel is touched by two bands, which represent the shared qualities of each element; water and air were both considered "moist" in classical philosophy, and air and fire were both considered "hot".']
reference_answer:
The present high altar and screen at Westminster Abbey were designed by George Gilbert Scott between 1867 and 1873. Notable contributions to this design include sculptures of Moses, St Peter, St Paul, and King David by H. H. Armistead, as well as a mosaic of the Last Supper created by J. R. Clayton and Antonio Salviati.

These elements together form part of the rich artistic heritage within Westminster Abbey, reflecting both historical craftsmanship and religious significance.

reference_answer:
The Cosmati pavement is a significant historical and artistic feature located at the crossing in front of Edward the Confessor's shrine and the main altar within Westminster Abbey. This intricate tile floor, created approximately 700 years ago, measures almost 25 feet square and was commissioned by Abbot Richard Ware after his visit to Rome in 1258. The pavement is made from nearly 30,000 pieces of colored glass and stone, showcasing a technique known as opus sectile ("cut work"), which involves cutting materials into various shapes rather than uniform sizes.

The materials used include colored glass, stones such as porphyry (originally quarried in Egypt), and dark Purbeck-marble trays. The use of these diverse materials highlights the craftsmanship and artistic innovation of the Cosmati family from Rome, who were renowned for their work during this period. Notably, the pavement features bold borders made with dark Purbeck marble instead of the more typical white marble used in other Cosmati floors across Europe.

The design of the Cosmati pavement is rich in geometric patterns and symbolism that reflect medieval Christian ideas about the universe. The floor's layout relies heavily on the geometric doubling of squares, a technique considered a trade secret among stonemasons at the time. This design includes four-sided squares, four-fold symmetry, and central roundels, which are symbolic representations of classical philosophy's four elements: earth, water, air, and fire. Each inner roundel is connected by bands that signify shared qualities between these elements—such as moisture for water and air, or heat for air and fire.

The central roundel represents the unformed state of the universe at its creation, embodying a theological perspective on the cosmos's origin and structure. This geometric design was not only an artistic endeavor but also served to aid the abbey’s monks in contemplation, providing a visual representation of complex medieval Christian ideas about the nature of the universe that were difficult to express verbally.

Overall, the Cosmati pavement is both an architectural masterpiece and a profound reflection of the spiritual and philosophical beliefs of its time.

query: Discuss the historical context and artistic importance of the Westminster Retable found within Westminster Abbey. When was it created, and what makes it significant as an English panel painting altarpiece?
reference_contexts:
['== Artworks and treasures ==
The nave and transepts have sixteen crystal chandeliers made of hand-blown Waterford glass. Designed by A. B. Read and Stephen Dykes Bower, they were donated by the Guinness family in 1965 to commemorate the abbey's 900th anniversary. The choir stalls were designed by Edward Blore in 1848. Some stalls are assigned to high commissioners of countries in the Commonwealth of Nations.
Beyond the crossing to the west is the sacrarium, which contains the high altar. The abbey has the 13th-century Westminster Retable, thought to be the altarpiece from Henry III's 13th-century church and the earliest surviving English panel painting altatrpiece, in its collections. The present high altar and screen were designed by George Gilbert Scott between 1867 and 1873, with sculptures of Moses, St Peter, St Paul, and King David by H. H. Armistead, as well as a mosaic of the Last Supper by J. R. Clayton and Antonio Salviati.
The south transept contains wall paintings made c. 1300, which Richard Jenkyns calls "the grandest of their time remaining in England". Depicting Thomas the Apostle looking at Christ's wounds and St Christopher carrying the Christ Child, the paintings were discovered in 1934 behind two monuments. Fourteenth-century paintings are on the backs of the sedilia (seats used by priests on either side of the high altar). On the south side are three figures: Edward the Confessor, the angel Gabriel, and the Virgin Mary. On the north side are two kings (possibly Henry III and Edward I) surrounding a religious figure, possibly St Peter. They were walled off during the Commonwealth period by order of Parliament, and were later rediscovered.
Over the Great West Door are ten statues of 20th-century Christian martyrs of various denominations; the statues were sculpted by the abbey's craftsmen in 1998. Those commemorated are Maximilian Kolbe, Manche Masemola, Janani Luwum, Grand Duchess Elizabeth Feodorovna, Martin Luther King Jr., Óscar Romero, Dietrich Bonhoeffer, Esther John, Lucian Tapiedi, and Wang Zhiming.
From the chapter house is a doorway leading to the abbey's library, which was built as a dormitory for the monks and has been used as a library since the 16th century. The collection has about 16,000 volumes. Next to the library is the Muniment Room, where the abbey's historic archives are kept.


=== Cosmati pavement ===

At the crossing in front of Edward the Confessor's shrine and the main altar is the Cosmati pavement, a 700-year-old tile floor made of almost 30,000 pieces of coloured glass and stone. Measuring almost 25 feet square, coronations take place here.
The floor is named after the Cosmati family in Rome, who were known for such work. It was commissioned by Richard Ware, who travelled to Rome in 1258, when he became abbot, and returned with stone and artists. The porphyry used was originally quarried as far away as Egypt, and was presumably brought to Italy during the Roman Empire. It was surrounded by a Latin inscription in brass letters (since lost) identifying the artist as Odericus, probably referring to designer Pietro di Oderisio or his son. The inscription also predicted the end of the world 19,863 years after its creation. Unlike traditional mosaic work, the pieces were not cut to a uniform size but made using a technique known as opus sectile ("cut work"). It is unique among Cosmati floors in Europe for the use of dark Purbeck-marble trays, forming bold borders, instead of the more typical white marble. The pavement influenced later floor treatments at St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle, and Canterbury Cathedral.
Geometric designs, such as those in the pavement, were thought to help the abbey's monks with contemplation, and conveyed medieval Christian ideas on the nature of the universe that could not easily be put into words. Much of the design relies on the geometric doubling of the square, considered a trade secret by stonemasons. The four-sided squares, four-fold symmetry, and the four inner roundels of the design represent the four elements of classical philosophy, with the central roundel representing the unformed state of the universe at its creation. Each inner roundel is touched by two bands, which represent the shared qualities of each element; water and air were both considered "moist" in classical philosophy, and air and fire were both considered "hot".']
reference_answer:
The Westminster Retable is a significant artifact housed in Westminster Abbey, notable for being one of the earliest surviving English panel painting altarpieces. Created in the 13th century during the reign of King Henry III, this retable is believed to have originated from Henry's church at that time. Its historical context is deeply intertwined with the medieval period when religious art played a crucial role in both worship and the expression of theological ideas.

The artistic importance of the Westminster Retable lies in its status as an early example of panel painting in England, marking a significant development in English art history. Panel paintings were relatively rare during this time, making the retable a valuable piece for understanding the evolution of religious art in medieval England. The use of panels allowed for more detailed and durable artworks compared to frescoes or wall paintings, which were more common.

The retable's significance is further enhanced by its connection to Henry III, who was known for his patronage of the arts and architecture, including the rebuilding of Westminster Abbey itself. This period saw a flourishing of Gothic art and architecture in England, with an emphasis on intricate detail and symbolism, both of which are reflected in the craftsmanship of the retable.

As an altarpiece, the Westminster Retable would have served as a focal point for worship, depicting religious scenes or figures intended to inspire devotion and convey theological messages. Its survival through centuries makes it an invaluable artifact for historians and art scholars studying medieval English culture and religious practices.

In summary, the Westminster Retable is significant not only as one of the earliest examples of panel painting in England but also as a reflection of the artistic and cultural milieu of 13th-century England under Henry III's reign. Its preservation within Westminster Abbey underscores its enduring importance to both historical scholarship and the appreciation of medieval art.

query: Who designed and made the north rose window of Westminster Abbey, and what notable figures are depicted in it?
reference_contexts:
["=== Stained glass ===

The abbey's 13th-century windows would have been filled with stained glass, but much of this was destroyed in the English Civil War and the Blitz and was replaced with clear, plain glass. Since the 19th century, new stained glass, designed by artists such as Ninian Comper (on the north side of the nave) and Hugh Easton and Alan Younger (in the Henry VII Chapel), has replaced clear glass.
The north rose window was designed by James Thornhill and made by Joshua Price in 1722; it shows Christ, the apostles (without Judas Iscariot), the Four Evangelists, and, in the centre, the Bible. The window was restored by J. L. Pearson in the 19th century, during which the feet of the figures were cut off. Thornhill also designed the great west window, which shows the Biblical figures of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, as well as representatives of the Twelve Tribes of Israel underneath.
In the Henry VII Chapel, the west window was designed by John Lawson and unveiled in 1995. It depicts coats of arms and cyphers of Westminster Abbey's benefactors, particularly John Templeton (whose coat of arms is prominent in the lower panel). In the centre are the arms of Elizabeth II. The central east window, designed by Alan Younger and dedicated to the Virgin Mary, was unveiled in 2000. It depicts Comet Hale–Bopp, which was passing over the artist's house at the time, as the star of Bethlehem. The donors of the window, Lord and Lady Harris of Peckham, are shown kneeling at the bottom.
In 2018, artist David Hockney unveiled a new stained-glass window for the north transept to celebrate the reign of Elizabeth II. It shows a country scene inspired by his native Yorkshire, with hawthorn blossoms and blue skies. Hockney used an iPad to design the window, replicating the backlight that comes through stained glass.


=== Queen's Diamond Jubilee Galleries ===

The Westminster Abbey Museum was located in the 11th-century vaulted undercroft beneath the former monks' dormitory. This is one of the oldest areas of the abbey, dating almost to the foundation of the church by Edward the Confessor in 1065. This space had been used as a museum since 1908, but was closed to the public when it was replaced as a museum in June 2018 by the Queen's Diamond Jubilee Galleries (high in the abbey's triforium and accessed through the Weston Tower, which encloses a lift and stairs).
The exhibits include a set of life-size effigies of English and British monarchs and their consorts, originally made to lie on the coffin in the funeral procession or to be displayed over the tomb. The effigies date from the 14th to the 18th centuries, and some include original clothes.
On display in the galleries is The Coronation Theatre, Westminster Abbey: A Portrait of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, a portrait by Ralph Heimans of the queen standing on the Cosmati pavement where she was crowned in 1953. Other exhibits include a model of an unbuilt tower designed by Christopher Wren; a paper model of the abbey as it was for Queen Victoria's 1837 coronation; and the wedding licence of Prince William and Catherine Middleton, who were married in the abbey in 2011."]
reference_answer: The north rose window of Westminster Abbey was designed by James Thornhill and made by Joshua Price in 1722. Notable figures depicted in this window include Christ, the apostles (excluding Judas Iscariot), the Four Evangelists, and, at the center, the Bible. The window underwent restoration in the 19th century by J. L. Pearson, during which the feet of the figures were cut off.

reference_answer:
The stained-glass window unveiled by artist David Hockney in 2018 for the north transept of Westminster Abbey holds significant cultural and artistic value. This window was created to celebrate the reign of Queen Elizabeth II, marking her long-standing service as a monarch. The design features a country scene inspired by Hockney's native Yorkshire, characterized by hawthorn blossoms and blue skies, which reflects both his personal connection to the landscape and a broader appreciation for British natural beauty.

Hockney utilized modern technology in its creation, designing the window using an iPad. This innovative approach allowed him to replicate the backlight effect typical of stained glass, merging traditional art forms with contemporary digital techniques. The use of such technology underscores Hockney's reputation as a pioneering artist who embraces new methods while respecting classical artistic traditions.

The installation of this window in Westminster Abbey, a site steeped in history and tradition, further enhances its significance. It represents the blending of modern artistry with historical reverence, contributing to the ongoing narrative of the abbey's architectural and cultural evolution. The window not only commemorates Queen Elizabeth II but also adds to the rich tapestry of stained glass that adorns the historic building, continuing a legacy of artistic contributions by notable artists like Ninian Comper, Hugh Easton, Alan Younger, and James Thornhill.

The comet is depicted as the star of Bethlehem in this stained-glass design.

query: Who was the first poet buried in Poets' Corner, and what role did he hold that connected him to Westminster Abbey?
reference_contexts:
['== Burials and memorials ==

Over 3,300 people are buried or commemorated in the abbey. For much of its history, most of the people buried there (other than monarchs) were people with a connection to the church – either ordinary locals or the monks of the abbey, who were generally buried without surviving markers. Since the 18th century, it has been an honour for any British person to be buried or commemorated in the abbey – a practice boosted by the lavish funeral and monument of Isaac Newton, who died in 1727. By 1900, so many prominent figures were buried in the abbey that the writer William Morris called it a "National Valhalla".
Politicians buried in the abbey include Pitt the Elder, Charles James Fox, Pitt the Younger, William Wilberforce, William Gladstone, and Clement Attlee. A cluster of scientists surrounds the tomb of Isaac Newton, including Charles Darwin and Stephen Hawking. Actors include David Garrick, Henry Irving, and Laurence Olivier. Musicians tend to be buried in the north aisle of the nave, and include Henry Purcell and Ralph Vaughan Williams. George Frideric Handel is buried in Poets' Corner.

An estimated 18 English, Scottish and British monarchs are buried in the abbey, including Edward the Confessor, Henry III, Edward I, Edward III, Richard II, Henry V, Edward V, Henry VII, Edward VI, Mary I, Mary Queen of Scots, Elizabeth I, James I, Charles II, Mary II, William III, Queen Anne, and George II. Elizabeth and Mary Queen of Scots were the last monarchs to be buried with full tomb effigies; monarchs buried after them are commemorated in the abbey with simple inscriptions. George II was the last monarch to be buried in the abbey, in 1760, and George III's brother, Henry Frederick, was the last member of the royal family to be buried in the abbey, in 1790. Most monarchs after George II have been buried in St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle, or at the Frogmore Royal Burial Ground, east of Windsor Castle.


=== Poets' Corner ===

The south transept of the church is known as Poets' Corner because of its high number of burials of, and memorials to, poets and writers. The first was Geoffrey Chaucer (buried around 1400), who was employed as Clerk of the King's Works and had apartments in the abbey. A second poet, Edmund Spenser (who was local to the abbey), was buried nearby in 1599. The idea of a Poets' Corner did not crystallise until the 18th century, when memorials were established to writers buried elsewhere, such as William Shakespeare and John Milton. Since then, writers buried in Poets' Corner have included John Dryden, Alfred, Lord Tennyson, Charles Dickens, and Rudyard Kipling. Not all writers buried in the abbey are in the south transept; Ben Jonson is buried standing upright in the north aisle of the nave, and Aphra Behn in the cloisters.


=== The Unknown Warrior ===

On the floor, just inside the Great West Door in the centre of the nave, is the grave of the Unknown Warrior: an unidentified soldier killed on a European battlefield during the First World War. Although many countries have a Tomb of the Unknown Soldier (or Warrior), the one in Westminster Abbey was the first; it came about as a response to the unprecedented death toll of the war. The idea came from army chaplain David Railton, who suggested it in 1920. The funeral was held on 11 November 1920, the second anniversary of the end of the war. The Unknown Warrior lay in state for a week afterwards, and an estimated 1.25 million people viewed his gravesite in that time. This grave is the only floor stone in the abbey on which it is forbidden to walk, and every visit by a foreign head of state begins with a visit to it.']
reference_answer: The first poet buried in Poets' Corner at Westminster Abbey was Geoffrey Chaucer. He held the position of Clerk of the King's Works, which connected him to the abbey as it involved overseeing royal building projects and maintaining properties for the king. Additionally, Chaucer had apartments within the abbey itself, further linking his life and work to this historic site.

reference_answer:
The last British monarchs noted for having full tomb effigies at their burial site in Westminster Abbey were Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots. After them, monarchs were commemorated with simple inscriptions rather than full effigies.

Most subsequent monarchs after George II were buried elsewhere; specifically, they were typically interred at St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle, or at the Frogmore Royal Burial Ground, which is located east of Windsor Castle.

query: Describe the significance of the Unknown Warrior's grave in Westminster Abbey and explain why it is unique compared to other gravesites within the abbey.
reference_contexts:
['== Burials and memorials ==

Over 3,300 people are buried or commemorated in the abbey. For much of its history, most of the people buried there (other than monarchs) were people with a connection to the church – either ordinary locals or the monks of the abbey, who were generally buried without surviving markers. Since the 18th century, it has been an honour for any British person to be buried or commemorated in the abbey – a practice boosted by the lavish funeral and monument of Isaac Newton, who died in 1727. Politicians buried in the abbey include Pitt the Elder, Charles James Fox, Pitt the Younger, William Wilberforce, William Gladstone, and Clement Attlee. A cluster of scientists surrounds the tomb of Isaac Newton, including Charles Darwin and Stephen Hawking. Actors include David Garrick, Henry Irving, and Laurence Olivier. === Poets' Corner ===

Since then, writers buried in Poets' Corner have included John Dryden, Alfred, Lord Tennyson, Charles Dickens, and Rudyard Kipling. Not all writers buried in the abbey are in the south transept; Ben Jonson is buried standing upright in the north aisle of the nave, and Aphra Behn in the cloisters.


=== The Unknown Warrior ===

On the floor, just inside the Great West Door in the centre of the nave, is the grave of the Unknown Warrior: an unidentified soldier killed on a European battlefield during the First World War. Although many countries have a Tomb of the Unknown Soldier (or Warrior), the one in Westminster Abbey was the first; it came about as a response to the unprecedented death toll of the war. The idea came from army chaplain David Railton, who suggested it in 1920. The funeral was held on 11 November 1920, the second anniversary of the end of the war. The Unknown Warrior lay in state for a week afterwards, and an estimated 1.25 million people viewed his gravesite in that time. This grave is the only floor stone in the abbey on which it is forbidden to walk, and every visit by a foreign head of state begins with a visit to it.']
reference_answer:
The grave of the Unknown Warrior in Westminster Abbey holds significant historical and symbolic importance. It represents an unidentified soldier who died on a European battlefield during World War I, serving as a poignant symbol for all soldiers who lost their lives in the conflict but whose remains were never identified or returned to their families. The creation of this memorial was driven by army chaplain David Railton's idea in 1920, aiming to honor and remember the countless unknown sacrifices made during the war.

The Unknown Warrior's grave is unique within Westminster Abbey for several reasons:

1. **First of Its Kind**: It was the first Tomb of the Unknown Soldier or Warrior established anywhere in the world. This pioneering act set a precedent that many other countries followed, creating their own memorials to honor unidentified soldiers from various conflicts.

2. **Central Location and Accessibility**: The grave is located on the floor just inside the Great West Door at the center of the nave, making it one of the most accessible and prominent sites within the abbey. This central placement underscores its importance as a focal point for remembrance.

3. **Prohibition Against Walking**: Unlike other gravesites in Westminster Abbey, where visitors may walk over them, it is forbidden to step on the stone marking the Unknown Warrior's grave. This restriction highlights the reverence and respect accorded to this particular memorial.

4. **Ceremonial Significance**: The funeral of the Unknown Warrior was held on November 11, 1920, coinciding with the second anniversary of the end of World War I. During a week-long lying in state, an estimated 1.25 million people visited the gravesite to pay their respects, reflecting its profound impact and significance.

5. **Diplomatic Protocol**: Every visit by a foreign head of state begins with a visit to the Unknown Warrior's grave, emphasizing its role as a symbol of international peace and reconciliation following the devastation of World War I.

Overall, the Unknown Warrior's grave serves as a powerful reminder of the human cost of war and the importance of honoring those who have fallen without recognition. Its unique status within Westminster Abbey underscores its enduring legacy as a site of collective memory and respect for all soldiers lost in battle.

query: Describe the significance of Westminster Abbey's design changes made during Henry III's reign and how they were intended to accommodate future events.
reference_contexts:
['== Royal occasions ==
The abbey has strong connections with the royal family. It has been patronised by monarchs, been the location for coronations, royal weddings and funerals, and several monarchs have attended services there. One monarch was born and one died at Westminster Abbey. In 1413, Henry IV collapsed while praying at the shrine of Edward the Confessor. He was moved into the Jerusalem Chamber, and died shortly afterwards. Edward V was born in the abbot's house in 1470.

The first jubilee celebration held at the abbey was for Queen Victoria's Golden Jubilee in 1887. Rather than wearing the full regalia that she had worn at her coronation, she wore her black mourning clothes topped with the insignia of the Order of the Garter and a miniature crown. She sat in the Coronation Chair—which received a coat of dark varnish for the occasion, which was painstakingly removed afterwards—making her the only monarch to sit in the chair twice. Queen Elizabeth II and her husband, Prince Philip, marked their silver, gold, and diamond wedding anniversaries with services at the abbey and regularly attended annual observances there for Commonwealth Day.
The monarch participates in the Office of the Royal Maundy on Maundy Thursday each year, during which selected elderly people (as many people of each sex as the monarch has years of their life) receive alms of coins. The service has been held at churches around the country since 1952, returning to the abbey every 10 years.


=== Coronations ===

Since the coronation of William the Conqueror in 1066, 40 English and British monarchs have been crowned in Westminster Abbey (not counting Edward V, Lady Jane Grey, and Edward VIII, who were never crowned). In 1216, Henry III could not be crowned in the abbey because London was occupied by hostile forces at the time. Henry was crowned in Gloucester Cathedral, and had a second coronation at Westminster Abbey in 1220. When he had the abbey rebuilt, it was designed with long transepts to accommodate many guests at future coronations. Much of the order of service derives from the Liber Regalis, an illuminated manuscript made in 1377 for the coronation of Richard II and held in the abbey's collections. On 6 May 2023, the coronation of Charles III took place at the abbey. The area used in the church is the crossing, known in the abbey as "the theatre" because of its suitability for grand events. The space in the crossing is clear rather than filled with immovable pews (like many similar churches), allowing for temporary seating in the transepts.

The Coronation Chair (the throne on which English and British sovereigns are seated when they are crowned) is in the abbey's St George's Chapel near the west door, and has been used at coronations since the 14th century. From 1301 to 1996 (except for a short time in 1950, when the stone was stolen by Scottish nationalists), the chair housed the Stone of Scone upon which the kings of Scots were crowned. Although it has been kept in Scotland at Edinburgh Castle since 1996, the stone is returned to the Coronation Chair in the abbey as needed for coronations. The chair was accessible to the public during the 18th and 19th centuries; people could sit in it, and some carved initials into the woodwork.
Before the 17th century, a king would hold a separate coronation for his new queen if he married after his coronation. The last of these to take place in the abbey was the coronation of Anne Boleyn in 1533, after her marriage to Henry VIII. Fifteen coronations of queens consort have been held in the abbey. A coronation for Jane Seymour, Henry VIII's third wife, was planned but she died before it took place; no coronations were planned for Henry's subsequent wives. Mary I's husband, Philip of Spain, was not given a separate coronation due to concerns that he would attempt to rule alone after Mary's death. Since then, there have been few opportunities for a second coronation; monarchs have generally come to the throne already married.
Henry II held a coronation ceremony at Westminster Abbey in 1170 for his son, known as Henry the Young King, while Henry II was still alive in an attempt to secure the succession. However, the Young King died before his father and never took the throne.']
reference_answer:
During the reign of Henry III, significant design changes were made to Westminster Abbey with the intention of accommodating large gatherings for important royal events. Initially, Henry III could not be crowned at the abbey in 1216 due to hostile forces occupying London; instead, he was crowned at Gloucester Cathedral and later had a second coronation at Westminster Abbey in 1220.

Recognizing the importance of the abbey as a venue for future coronations and other royal ceremonies, Henry III undertook extensive rebuilding efforts. One key design change was the extension of the transepts to make them longer. This architectural modification was specifically intended to accommodate many guests during grand events such as coronations. The extended transepts allowed more space for seating large numbers of attendees, ensuring that future gatherings could be held with greater capacity and formality.

Additionally, much of the order of service for these ceremonies derives from the "Liber Regalis," an illuminated manuscript created in 1377 for Richard II's coronation, which is housed within the abbey. This document helped standardize the ceremonial aspects of royal events held at Westminster Abbey.

Overall, Henry III’s design changes were strategic and forward-thinking, aimed at enhancing the abbey's functionality as a central location for significant royal occasions, ensuring it could host large audiences with dignity and grandeur.

reference_answer:
The Coronation Chair at Westminster Abbey holds significant historical importance as it has been used for the coronations of English and British monarchs since the 14th century. Located in St George's Chapel near the west door, this chair is a central symbol of royal authority and tradition.

One of its most notable features is that it houses the Stone of Scone, also known as "Jacob's Stone." This stone has been used for centuries in the coronation ceremonies of Scottish kings and later British monarchs. From 1301 until 1996, with a brief interruption when it was stolen by Scottish nationalists in 1950, the Stone of Scone rested atop the Coronation Chair at Westminster Abbey. Although the stone is now kept at Edinburgh Castle, it is returned to the chair for coronations as needed.

The historical significance of the Coronation Chair extends beyond its role in royal ceremonies. During the 18th and 19th centuries, the chair was accessible to the public, allowing people to sit on it. This accessibility led some individuals to carve their initials into the woodwork, leaving a tangible mark of personal interaction with this symbol of monarchy.

Overall, the Coronation Chair is not only an artifact of royal tradition but also a piece of living history that connects the past with the present through its ceremonial use and public interactions over the centuries.

query: Discuss the circumstances surrounding the coronations held for queens consort at Westminster Abbey, highlighting any exceptions or unique cases mentioned in the context information.

reference_answer:
The context provides insights into the historical practice of crowning queens consort at Westminster Abbey, with several notable exceptions and unique cases:

1. **Separate Coronation Ceremonies**: Before the 17th century, it was customary for a king to hold a separate coronation ceremony for his new queen if he married after his own coronation. This tradition allowed queens consort to be crowned in their own right.

2. **Anne Boleyn's Coronation (1533)**: The last instance of such a separate coronation at Westminster Abbey was for Anne Boleyn, the second wife of Henry VIII, following her marriage to him. Her coronation marked the end of this practice within the abbey.

3. **Exceptions and Non-Coronations**:
   - **Jane Seymour**: A coronation was planned for Jane Seymour, Henry VIII's third wife, but she died before it could take place.
   - **Subsequent Wives of Henry VIII**: No coronations were held for Henry VIII’s later wives—Catherine Howard, Catherine Parr, and Anne of Cleves—likely due to the political and personal complexities following his marriage to Anne Boleyn.

4. **Philip II of Spain**: Mary I's husband, Philip of Spain, did not receive a separate coronation as queen consort. This decision was influenced by concerns that he might attempt to rule independently after Mary’s death.

5. **General Trend Post-17th Century**: Since the 17th century, opportunities for separate coronations have been rare because monarchs typically ascended the throne already married, reducing the need for a distinct ceremony for their consorts.

6. **Unique Case of Henry the Young King (1170)**: Although not directly related to queens consort, an interesting historical note is that Henry II held a coronation at Westminster Abbey in 1170 for his son, Henry the Young King, while still alive. This was intended to secure succession but did not result in him taking the throne as he died before his father.

These points highlight how political, personal, and dynastic considerations influenced the practice of crowning queens consort at Westminster Abbey, with Anne Boleyn's coronation standing out as a significant exception in this historical context.

query: What significant change occurred in royal wedding traditions at Westminster Abbey starting with Princess Mary's wedding in 1922, and what practice did Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon introduce during her wedding in 1923?
reference_contexts:
["=== Weddings ===
At least 16 royal weddings have taken place at the abbey. Royal weddings at the abbey were relatively rare before the 20th century, with royals often married in a Chapel Royal or at Windsor Castle; this changed with the 1922 wedding of Princess Mary at the abbey. In 1923, Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon became the first royal bride to leave her bouquet on the grave of the Unknown Warrior, a practice continued by many royal brides since.

Royal weddings have included:


=== Funerals ===
Many royal funerals took place at the abbey between that of Edward the Confessor in 1066 and that of Prince Henry, the last royal buried in the church, in 1790. There were no royal funerals at the abbey from then until that of Queen Alexandra in 1925; the queen was buried in Windsor Castle. Other queen consorts, such as Mary of Teck in 1953 and Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother in 2002, have also had funerals at the abbey before being buried elsewhere.
On 6 September 1997, the ceremonial funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales was held at the abbey. Before the funeral, the railings of the abbey were swamped with flowers and tributes. The event was more widely seen than any previous occasion in the abbey's history, with 2 billion television viewers worldwide. Diana was buried privately on a private island at Althorp, her family estate.
On 19 September 2022, the state funeral of Elizabeth II took place at the abbey before her burial at St George's Chapel, Windsor. It was the first funeral of a monarch at Westminster Abbey for more than 260 years.


== People ==


=== Dean and Chapter ===

Westminster Abbey is a collegiate church governed by the Dean and Chapter of Westminster as established by a royal charter from Elizabeth I dated 21 May 1560, which created it as the Collegiate Church of St Peter Westminster (a royal peculiar). In 2019, David Hoyle was appointed Dean of Westminster. The chapter consists of four canons and a senior administrative officer, known as the Receiver General. One of the canons is also rector of the adjoining St Margaret's Church, Westminster, and is often the chaplain of the Speaker of the House of Commons. In addition to the dean and canons, there are minor canons.


=== King's almsmen ===
Six King's (or Queen's) almsmen and women are supported by the abbey. They are appointed by royal warrant on the recommendation of the dean and the Home Secretary, attend Matins and Evensong on Sundays, and perform requested duties for a small stipend. On duty, they wear a distinctive red gown with a crowned rose badge on the left shoulder.
The almshouse was founded near the abbey by Henry VII in 1502, and the twelve almsmen and three almswomen were originally minor court officials who were retired due to age or disability. They were required to be over the age of 50, single, with a good reputation, literate, able to look after themselves, and with an income of under £4 per year. The building survived the Dissolution of the Monasteries, but was demolished for road-widening in 1779. From the late 18th to the late 20th century, almsmen were usually old soldiers and sailors; today, they are primarily retired abbey employees.


=== Schools ===

Westminster School is in the abbey. Instruction has taken place since the 14th century with the monks of the abbey; the school regards its founder as Elizabeth I, who dissolved the monastery for the last time and provided for the establishment of the school, the dean, canons, assistant clergy, and lay officers. The schoolboys were rambunctious; Westminster boys have defaced the Coronation Chair, disrupted services, and once interrupted the consecration of four bishops with a bare-knuckle fight in the cloisters. One schoolboy carved on the Coronation Chair that he had slept in it overnight, making him probably its longest inhabitant. Westminster School became independent of the abbey Dean and Chapter in 1868, although the institutions remain closely connected. Westminster Abbey Choir School, also on the abbey grounds, educates the choirboys who sing for abbey services."]
reference_answer:
Starting with Princess Mary's wedding in 1922, a significant change in royal wedding traditions occurred at Westminster Abbey. Before the 20th century, it was relatively rare for royals to be married there; they often chose Chapels Royal or Windsor Castle instead. However, Princess Mary's wedding marked a shift towards using Westminster Abbey as a venue for royal weddings.

In addition to this change, Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon introduced a new practice during her wedding in 1923. She became the first royal bride to leave her bouquet on the grave of the Unknown Warrior at Westminster Abbey. This act has since been continued by many royal brides following her example.

reference_answer:
The state funeral of Queen Elizabeth II, held on September 19, 2022, at Westminster Abbey, holds significant historical importance for several reasons:

1. **First Monarch's Funeral in Over 260 Years**: This event marked the first time a monarch was buried at Westminster Abbey since 1760, when Prince Henry was laid to rest there. The last royal funeral before Elizabeth II's took place over two and a half centuries ago, making this occasion particularly momentous.

2. **Symbolic Venue**: Westminster Abbey has been a central site for British royal ceremonies, including coronations, weddings, and funerals. Hosting the state funeral of Queen Elizabeth II underscored her status as a pivotal figure in modern British history and highlighted the abbey's enduring role in national traditions.

3. **Global Attention**: Similar to the ceremonial funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales in 1997, which was widely viewed worldwide, Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral attracted global attention. It served not only as a moment of mourning but also as an opportunity for people around the world to reflect on her long reign and its impact.

4. **Cultural and Historical Continuity**: The event connected contemporary Britain with its historical past, emphasizing continuity in royal traditions and ceremonies that have been part of British heritage for centuries.

5. **Commemoration of a Long Reign**: Queen Elizabeth II's 70-year reign was the longest of any British monarch, making her funeral a significant moment to commemorate her contributions and legacy both within the United Kingdom and across the Commonwealth.

Overall, the state funeral at Westminster Abbey was not only a tribute to Queen Elizabeth II but also an affirmation of the abbey’s historical significance in royal ceremonies.

The King's (or Queen's) almsmen and women at Westminster Abbey have a unique role that combines ceremonial duties with providing support to the abbey. Here is an explanation of their responsibilities, attire, and appointment process:

### Responsibilities:
1. **Ceremonial Duties**: The almsmen and women attend Matins (morning prayers) and Evensong (evening prayers) on Sundays at Westminster Abbey.
2. **Service Requests**: They perform various duties as requested by the abbey for a small stipend, contributing to the daily operations and ceremonial functions of the institution.

### Attire:
- When on duty, they wear a distinctive red gown that features a crowned rose badge on the left shoulder. This attire is symbolic and marks their role within the abbey's traditions.

### Appointment Process:
1. **Recommendation**: The almsmen and women are appointed by royal warrant based on recommendations from both the Dean of Westminster and the Home Secretary.
2. **Historical Context**: Originally, these positions were filled by minor court officials who were retired due to age or disability. Over time, the criteria evolved, with many being old soldiers and sailors until recent times when they have primarily been retired abbey employees.

The King's almsmen and women thus play a supportive role in maintaining the traditions and operations of Westminster Abbey while also having historical significance tied to royal patronage.

query: What historical event led to the revival of the Most Honourable Order of the Bath, and who was responsible for this revival?
reference_contexts:
['=== Order of the Bath ===

The Most Honourable Order of the Bath is a British order of chivalry whose spiritual home is the abbey's Henry VII Chapel. The order was founded by George I in 1725, fell out of fashion after 1812, and was revived by George V in 1913. The name derives from the elaborate medieval ceremony for appointing a knight, which included bathing as a symbol of purification. Members are given stalls with their banner, crest, and a stall plate at installation ceremonies in the abbey every four years. Since there are more members than stalls, some members wait many years for their installation. The Order of the Bath is the fourth-oldest British orders of chivalry, after the Orders of the Garter, the Thistle, and St Patrick (the latter is presently dormant).


== Music ==

Andrew Nethsingha has been the abbey's organist and master of the choristers since 2023. Peter Holder is the sub-organist, Matthew Jorysz the assistant organist, and Dewi Rees is the organ scholar.


=== Choir ===
Since its foundation in the 14th century, the primary role of the Westminster Abbey choir has been to sing for daily services; the choir also plays a central role in many state occasions, including royal weddings and funerals, coronations, and memorial services. In 2012, the choir accepted an invitation from Pope Benedict XVI to sing with the Sistine Chapel Choir at a Papal Mass in St Peter's Basilica. The all-male choir consists of twelve professional adult singers and thirty boy choristers from eight to 13 years old who attend the Westminster Abbey Choir School.


=== Organ ===
The first record of an organ at Westminster Abbey was the mention of a gift of three marks from Henry III in 1240 for the repair of one (or more) organs. Unum parem organorum ("a pair of organs") was recorded in the Lady Chapel in 1304. An inventory compiled for the Dissolution of the Monasteries in 1540 lists a pair of organs in the choir and one in the Islip Chapel. During the Commonwealth, a Royalist source said that soldiers who were billeted in the abbey "brake downe the Organ, and pawned the pipes at severall Ale-houses for pots of Ale"; an organ was played at the Restoration in 1660, however, suggesting that it had not been completely destroyed. In 1720, an organ gifted by George II and built by Christopher Shrider was installed over the choir screen; organs had previously been hidden on the north side of the choir. The organ was rebuilt by William Hill & Son in 1848.
A new organ was built by Harrison & Harrison in 1937, with four manuals and 84 speaking stops, and was played publicly for the first time at the coronation of George VI and Elizabeth that year. Some pipework from the previous Hill organ of 1848 was re-voiced and incorporated into the new instrument. The two organ cases, designed and built in the late 19th century by J. L. Pearson, were reinstated and coloured in 1959.
In 1982 and 1987, Harrison & Harrison enlarged the organ at the direction of Simon Preston to include an additional lower choir organ and a bombarde organ. The full instrument has five manuals and 109 speaking stops. Its console was refurbished by Harrison & Harrison in 2006, and space was prepared for two additional 16-foot stops on the lower choir organ and the bombarde organ. The abbey has three other organs: the two-manual Queen's Organ in the Lady Chapel, a smaller continuo organ, and a practice organ.


=== Bells ===
There have been bells at the abbey since at least the time of Henry III, and the current bells were installed in the north-west tower in 1971. The ring is made up of ten bells, hung for change ringing, which were cast in 1971 by the Whitechapel Bell Foundry and tuned to the musical notes F#, E, D, C#, B, A, G, F#, E and D. The tenor bell in D (588.5 Hz) has a weight of 30 cwt, 1 qtr, 15 lb (3,403 lb, or 1,544 kg). Two additional service bells were cast by Robert Mot in 1585 and 1598, and a sanctus bell was cast in 1738 by Richard Phelps and Thomas Lester. Two bells are unused; one was cast c. 1320, and the second was cast in 1742 by Thomas Lester. The Westminster Abbey Company of Ringers ring peals on special occasions, such as the wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton.']
reference_answer: The Most Honourable Order of the Bath fell out of fashion after 1812 but was revived by King George V in 1913. The context does not specify a particular historical event that directly led to its revival; however, it can be inferred that the early 20th century was a period when there was renewed interest in chivalric orders and traditions within Britain. King George V's decision to revive the order reflects this broader cultural trend during his reign.

query: In which play by William Shakespeare and John Fletcher is Westminster Abbey mentioned, particularly in relation to Anne Boleyn's coronation?
reference_contexts:
['== In popular culture ==

Westminster Abbey is mentioned in the play Henry VIII by William Shakespeare and John Fletcher, when a gentleman describes Anne Boleyn's coronation. The abbey was mentioned in a 1598 sonnet by Thomas Bastard which begins, "When I behold, with deep astonishment / To famous Westminster how there restort / Living in brass or stony monument / The princes and the worthies of all sort". Poetry about the abbey has also been written by Francis Beaumont and John Betjeman. The building has appeared in paintings by artists such as Canaletto, Wenceslaus Hollar, William Bruce Ellis Ranken, and J. M. W. Turner.
Playwright Alan Bennett produced The Abbey, a 1995 documentary recounting his experiences of the building. Key scenes in the book and film The Da Vinci Code take place in Westminster Abbey. The abbey refused to allow filming in 2005 (calling the book "theologically unsound"), and the film uses Lincoln Cathedral as a stand-in. The abbey issued a fact sheet to their staff which answered questions and debunked several claims made in the book. In 2022, it was announced that the abbey had given rare permission to film inside the church for Mission: Impossible – The Final Reckoning.


== See also ==

Archdeacon of Westminster
List of churches in London
Abbot of Westminster


== Notes and references ==


=== Notes ===


=== References ===


== External links ==

Official website']
reference_answer: Westminster Abbey is mentioned in the play "Henry VIII" by William Shakespeare and John Fletcher. It is referenced when a gentleman describes Anne Boleyn's coronation. This context highlights the historical significance of Westminster Abbey as it relates to royal ceremonies, such as coronations, which are central themes in the play.

The artists who have depicted Westminster Abbey in their paintings are Canaletto, Wenceslaus Hollar, William Bruce Ellis Ranken, and J. M. W. Turner. The context information mentions that the building has appeared in paintings by all these artists.

- **Canaletto**: Known for his landscapes and cityscapes, particularly of Venice, but he also painted views of London, including Westminster Abbey.
  
- **Wenceslaus Hollar**: A Bohemian artist known for his etchings, who created detailed works of London scenes, including Westminster Abbey.

- **William Bruce Ellis Ranken**: An artist whose work includes depictions of historical and architectural subjects, such as Westminster Abbey.

- **J. M. W. Turner**: Renowned for his expressive colorizations, imaginative landscapes, and turbulent marine paintings, he also painted views of significant buildings like Westminster Abbey.

Therefore, all four artists—Canaletto, Wenceslaus Hollar, William Bruce Ellis Ranken, and J. M. W. Turner—have depicted Westminster Abbey in their works.

query: Why did Westminster Abbey refuse permission for filming "The Da Vinci Code" on its premises in 2005?

reference_answer: Westminster Abbey refused permission for filming "The Da Vinci Code" on its premises in 2005 because it considered the book to be "theologically unsound." The abbey was concerned about the portrayal of religious themes and narratives presented in the story, which likely conflicted with their values or beliefs. As a result, they chose not to allow filming within the historic building and instead issued a fact sheet to their staff to address and debunk several claims made in the book. Consequently, Lincoln Cathedral was used as a stand-in for scenes that were intended to take place at Westminster Abbey.

query: In what year was the University of Edinburgh officially opened, and under whose authority was it founded?
reference_contexts:
['The University of Edinburgh (Scots: University o Edinburgh, Scottish Gaelic: Oilthigh Dhùn Èideann; abbreviated as Edin. in post-nominals) is a public research university based in Edinburgh, Scotland. Founded by the town council under the authority of a royal charter from King James VI in 1582 and officially opened in 1583,  it is one of Scotland's four ancient universities and the sixth-oldest university in continuous operation in the English-speaking world. The university played a crucial role in Edinburgh becoming a leading intellectual centre during the Scottish Enlightenment and contributed to the city being nicknamed the "Athens of the North".
The three main global university rankings (ARWU, THE, and QS) place the University of Edinburgh within their respective top 40. It is a member of several associations of research-intensive universities, including the Coimbra Group, League of European Research Universities, Russell Group, Una Europa, and Universitas 21. In the fiscal year ending 31 July 2024, the university had a total income of £1.386 billion, with £365.2 million from research grants and contracts. It has the third-largest endowment in the UK, behind only Cambridge and Oxford. The university occupies five main campuses in the city of Edinburgh, which include many buildings of historical and architectural significance, such as those in the Old Town.
Edinburgh is the fourth-largest university in the United Kingdom by total enrolment and receives over 66,000 undergraduate applications per year, making it the fifth-most popular university in the UK by application volume. In 2021, Edinburgh had the seventh-highest average UCAS points among British universities for new entrants. The university maintains strong links to the royal family, with Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, serving as its chancellor from 1953 to 2010, and Anne, Princess Royal, holding the position since March 2011.
Notable alumni of the University of Edinburgh include inventor Alexander Graham Bell, naturalist Charles Darwin, philosopher David Hume, physicist James Clerk Maxwell, and writers such as Oliver Goldsmith, Sir J. M. Barrie, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, Sir Walter Scott, and Robert Louis Stevenson.  The university has produced several heads of state and government, including three British prime ministers. Additionally, three UK Supreme Court justices were educated at Edinburgh. As of October 2024, the university has been affiliated with 20 Nobel Prize laureates, four Pulitzer Prize winners, three Turing Award winners, an Abel Prize laureate, and a Fields Medalist. Edinburgh alumni have also won a total of ten Olympic gold medals.


== History ==']
reference_answer: The University of Edinburgh was officially opened in 1583. It was founded by the town council under the authority of a royal charter from King James VI in 1582.
