reference_answer:
Charles Darwin's views on religion evolved significantly over time, particularly influenced by his marriage to Emma. Initially, Darwin was already skeptical about religious doctrines before he proposed to Emma in November 1838. He openly discussed his ideas on the transmutation of species with her and expressed concerns about how their differing beliefs might affect their relationship.

Emma, who held Unitarian beliefs emphasizing inner feeling over strict adherence to doctrine, valued open communication and honesty regarding personal beliefs. Despite her fears that differences in religious views could create a "painful void" between them, she encouraged Darwin to share his thoughts openly. This mutual openness was crucial for maintaining their bond despite differing perspectives.

After their marriage in January 1839, Darwin and Emma continued to engage in discussions about Christianity and religion more broadly. They socialized with Unitarian clergymen like James Martineau and John James Tayler, and read works by other liberal thinkers, which contributed to a rich environment of debate and exploration of religious ideas.

Emma's belief in the afterlife and her desire for them to "belong to each other" eternally influenced Darwin. Although he gradually developed agnosticism, Emma's support allowed him to maintain an open-minded approach to both nature and revelation. She reassured him that as long as he was acting conscientiously and sincerely seeking truth, he could not be wrong.

Darwin's methodical doubt—approaching beliefs with inquiry rather than outright disbelief—enabled him to remain receptive to new ideas. This attitude allowed for ongoing dialogue between Darwin and Emma, where they both respected each other's perspectives while exploring their own spiritual journeys. Their relationship exemplified how open communication and mutual respect can help navigate differences in belief without diminishing the closeness of a partnership.

query: What was the significance of "The Grove" after Emma Darwin's time, and what decision did Fitzwilliam College make regarding its gatehouse, Grove Lodge?
reference_contexts:
['== Later life and the Darwin grounds ==

Shortly before she turned 74, her husband Charles died at 73 on 19 April 1882. Subsequently, Emma spent the summers in Down House. She bought a large house called The Grove on Huntingdon Road in Cambridge, and lived there during the winters. Emma Darwin died in 1896. Her son Francis had a house, which he named Wychfield, built in the grounds of The Grove. He lived there during most winters, spending summers in Gloucestershire. Emma's son Horace also had a house built in the grounds, and named it The Orchard.
The Grove is now the central building of Fitzwilliam College, and provides common room facilities for graduates, Fellows and senior members. In January 2009, Cambridge City Council gave the College planning permission to demolish its gatehouse, Grove Lodge, which now forms part of Murray Edwards College. After local residents and academics expressed concern and there was a campaign against the demolition, the college council decided to reconsider possible alternative uses; their decision at the end of September 2009 was to keep and refurbish Grove Lodge. Architects, consultants and builders were appointed for conversion work, which when completed in September 2011 provided five new studies for Fellows.


== Children ==

The Darwins (after Charles' death in 1882, Emma and Francis) also brought up Francis' son Bernard Darwin (1876-1961) after the death of Bernard's mother a few days after he was born.


== Cultural references ==
In 2001 a biography of Emma was published written by Edna Healey, though it has been criticised for attempting to give credit to Emma for her husband's ideas, whereas other historians agree she had little, if any, scientific input.
In 2008 Mrs Charles Darwin's Recipe Book was published, with profits going to the Darwin Correspondence Project at Cambridge University.
The 2009 film Creation focuses in part on the relationship between Charles and Emma. Emma was played by Jennifer Connelly.
A boarding house at Shrewsbury School is named in her honour.


== Darwins buried at Downe ==
Eight members of the Darwin family are buried at St Mary's Church, Downe. Darwins buried at Downe include: Bernard Darwin and his wife Elinor Monsell, who taught her husband's cousin Gwen (Darwin) Raverat, engraver and author of Period Piece; Charles Waring Darwin; Elizabeth Darwin, "Aunt Bessy"; Emma Darwin, Charles Darwin's wife; Erasmus Alvey Darwin; Mary Eleanor Darwin; Henrietta Etty Darwin, later Litchfield, "Aunt Etty". Emma Darwin's sister Elizabeth Wedgwood and Aunt Sarah Wedgwood are also buried together at St Mary's.


== See also ==
Social history of the piano
Emma Darwin (novelist)
List of coupled cousins
Darwin–Wedgwood family
Emma Darwin: A Century of Family Letters


== Notes ==


== References ==
Browne, E. Janet (1995), Charles Darwin: vol. 1 Voyaging, London: Jonathan Cape, ISBN 1-84413-314-1
Browne, E. Janet (2002), Charles Darwin: vol. 2 The Power of Place, London: Jonathan Cape, ISBN 0-7126-6837-3
Darwin, Charles (1837–1838), Notebook B: [Transmutation of species], Darwin Online, CUL-DAR121, retrieved 20 December 2008
Darwin, Charles (1838), Notebook C: [Transmutation of species], Darwin Online
Darwin, Charles (1887), Darwin, Francis (ed.), The life and letters of Charles Darwin, including an autobiographical chapter, London: John Murray, retrieved 4 November 2008
Darwin, Charles (1958), Barlow, Nora (ed.), The Autobiography of Charles Darwin 1809–1882. With the original omissions restored. Edited and with appendix and notes by his granddaughter Nora Barlow, London: Collins, retrieved 4 November 2008
Desmond, Adrian; Moore, James (1991), Darwin, London: Michael Joseph, Penguin Group, ISBN 0-7181-3430-3
Freeman, R. B. (1984), . Darwin Pedigrees, London: printed for the author, retrieved 15 September 2009
Freeman, R. B. (2007), Charles Darwin: A companion (2d online ed.), The Complete Works of Charles Darwin Online, retrieved 18 June 2008
Litchfield, Henrietta Emma (1904), Emma Darwin, wife of Charles Darwin. A century of family letters, London: John Murray, retrieved 18 February 2013']
reference_answer:
### Significance of "The Grove" After Emma Darwin's Time

After Emma Darwin's era, "The Grove," which she had purchased on Huntingdon Road in Cambridge, became an integral part of Fitzwilliam College. It serves as the central building of the college and provides common room facilities for graduates, Fellows, and senior members. This transformation highlights its continued importance as a communal space within the academic community.

### Decision Regarding Grove Lodge

Initially, in January 2009, Cambridge City Council granted Fitzwilliam College planning permission to demolish its gatehouse, known as Grove Lodge, which had become part of Murray Edwards College. However, this decision faced opposition from local residents and academics who expressed concerns about the demolition. As a result, there was a campaign against it.

In response to these concerns, the college council reconsidered their plans and decided in September 2009 to keep and refurbish Grove Lodge instead of demolishing it. They appointed architects, consultants, and builders for conversion work, which was completed by September 2011. The refurbished Grove Lodge now provides five new studies for Fellows, thus preserving its historical significance while adapting it for contemporary use.

This decision reflects a balance between respecting the heritage of the site and meeting modern needs within the academic community.

reference_answer:
In the cultural reference provided, specifically the 2009 film "Creation," the relationship between Charles Darwin and his wife Emma is portrayed with a focus on their personal dynamics during a significant period of Charles's life. The film highlights the emotional and intellectual partnership between them, particularly as Charles grapples with the development and implications of his theory of evolution by natural selection.

Emma Darwin, played by Jennifer Connelly in the film, is depicted as a supportive yet complex figure in Charles's life. She provides him with both emotional support and critical feedback on his work. The film explores their relationship against the backdrop of Charles's scientific endeavors and personal struggles, including the death of their daughter Annie, which deeply affects both Charles and Emma.

"Creation" delves into how Emma influences Charles's thinking and writing process, suggesting that her insights and perspectives contribute to his ability to articulate his groundbreaking ideas. The film portrays a nuanced relationship where Emma is not just a passive supporter but an active participant in the intellectual journey of one of history's most influential scientists.

Overall, "Creation" presents their relationship as one marked by mutual respect, deep emotional connection, and significant influence on each other's lives and work.

Darwin, Charles (1958), Barlow, Nora (ed.), The Autobiography of Charles Darwin 1809–1882. With the original omissions restored. Edited and with appendix and notes by his granddaughter Nora Barlow, London: Collins, retrieved 4 November 2008
Desmond, Adrian; Moore, James (1991), Darwin, London: Michael Joseph, Penguin Group, ISBN 0-7181-3430-3
Freeman, R. B. (1984), . Darwin Pedigrees, London: printed for the author, retrieved 15 September 2009
Freeman, R. B. (2007), Charles Darwin: A companion (2d online ed.), The Complete Works of Charles Darwin Online, retrieved 18 June 2008
Litchfield, Henrietta Emma (1904), Emma Darwin, wife of Charles Darwin. A century of family letters, London: John Murray, retrieved 18 February 2013']
reference_answer:
Eight members of the Darwin family are buried at St. Mary's Church in Downe. Two individuals from this list include:

1. Emma Darwin, who was Charles Darwin's wife.
2. Henrietta Etty Darwin, later known as Litchfield and referred to as "Aunt Etty."

These individuals are part of a larger group that includes other family members such as Bernard Darwin, his wife Elinor Monsell, Charles Waring Darwin, Elizabeth Darwin ("Aunt Bessy"), Erasmus Alvey Darwin, Mary Eleanor Darwin, and Emma Darwin's sister Elizabeth Wedgwood along with Aunt Sarah Wedgwood.

query: In what year did the Geological Society of London receive its royal charter, and from which monarch?
reference_contexts:
['The Geological Society of London, known commonly as the Geological Society, is a learned society based in the United Kingdom. It is the oldest national geological society in the world and the largest in Europe, with more than 12,000 Fellows.
Fellows are entitled to the postnominal FGS (Fellow of the Geological Society), over 2,000 of whom are Chartered Geologists (CGeol). The Society is a registered charity, no. 210161. It is also a member of the Science Council, and is licensed to award Chartered Scientist to qualifying members.
The mission of the society is: "Making geologists acquainted with each other, stimulating their zeal, inducing them to adopt one nomenclature, facilitating the communication of new facts and ascertaining what is known in their science and what remains to be discovered".


== History ==
The Society was founded on 13 November 1807 at the Freemasons' Tavern, Great Queen Street, in the Covent Garden district of London. It was partly the outcome of a previous club known as the Askesian Society. There were 13 founder members: William Babington, James Parkinson, Humphry Davy, George Bellas Greenough, Arthur Aikin, William Allen, Jacques Louis, Comte de Bournon, Richard Knight, James Laird, James Franck, William Haseldine Pepys, Richard Phillips, and William Phillips. It received its royal charter on 23 April 1825 from George IV.
Since 1874, the Society has been based at Burlington House, Piccadilly, London. This building houses the Society's library, which contains more than 300,000 volumes of books and journals. It is a member of the UK Science Council.
In 1907 a decision was made by the Society to admit women as Associates, under the condition they distinguished themselves as geological investigators or submitted their own original research. Women were first allowed to become Fellows of the Society in 1919. Margaret Crosfield became the first, due to alphabetical primacy, of the first eight women to be elected Fellows of the Society, on 21 May 1919. 
In 1991, the Society merged with the Institution of Geologists, which had been formed in 1977 to represent the geological profession.
The Society is a member of the European Federation of Geologists.
The Society celebrated its bicentenary in 2007. It ran programmes in the geosciences in Britain and abroad, under the auspices of the science writer and palaeontologist Professor Richard Fortey, the president that year.


== Specialist and regional groups ==
The Society has 24 specialist groups and 15 regional groups which serve as an opportunity for those with specific interests to meet and discuss their subject or region. They are all free for members to join and some are open to non-members.
The Regional Groups are:

The Specialist Groups are:


== Publications ==
The society publishes two of its own journals, the (formerly Quarterly) Journal of the Geological Society and the Quarterly Journal of Engineering Geology & Hydrogeology. It also publishes the magazine Geoscientist for Fellows, and has a share in Geology Today, published by Blackwell Science.
It also co-publishes journals and publishes on behalf of other organisations. These include Petroleum Geoscience with the European Association of Geoscientists and Engineers; Geochemistry: Exploration, Environment, Analysis with the Association of Applied Geochemists; Journal of Micropalaeontology for The Micropalaeontological Society; Proceedings of the Yorkshire Geological Society for the Yorkshire Geological Society; and Scottish Journal of Geology for the Geological Societies of Edinburgh and Glasgow.


== Past presidents ==

The society counts many famous geologists amongst its past presidents. These include pioneers of geology William Buckland, Adam Sedgwick, Roderick Impey Murchison, Charles Lyell, Henry Thomas De la Beche, Thomas Henry Huxley, Joseph Prestwich, Archibald Geikie, Jethro Teall, and Charles Lapworth. Later well-known names include Alfred Harker, Arthur Elijah Trueman, Herbert Harold Read, Frederick Shotton, and Janet Watson.


== Scientific awards and funds ==
In 1831, it began issuing an annual scientific award for geology, known as the Wollaston Medal. This is still the Society's premier medal, which in 2006 was awarded to James Lovelock, the originator of the Gaia hypothesis.


=== Medals awarded by the Society ===
Aberconway Medal
Bigsby Medal
Dewey Medal
Distinguished Service Award
Lyell Medal
Major John Sacheverell A'Deane Coke Medal
Major Edward D'Ewes Fitzgerald Coke Medal
Murchison Medal
President's Awards
Prestwich Medal
R. H. Worth Award
Sue Tyler Friedman Medal
William Smith Medal
Wollaston Medal']
reference_answer: The Geological Society of London received its royal charter on 23 April 1825 from George IV.

reference_answer:
Margaret Crosfield's election as a Fellow of the Geological Society in 1919 holds significant historical importance for several reasons:

1. **Pioneering Role for Women**: Her election marked a pivotal moment in the history of gender equality within the geological community and scientific societies at large. Before 1919, women were only admitted as Associates under specific conditions, but not as Fellows. Crosfield's election was a breakthrough that paved the way for greater inclusion of women in professional geology.

2. **First Female Fellow**: Margaret Crosfield became one of the first eight women to be elected as Fellows of the Geological Society on 21 May 1919. Her position, due to alphabetical primacy among those elected, underscores her pioneering role and highlights the beginning of a new era for female participation in geology.

3. **Symbolic Milestone**: This event symbolized progress towards gender equality within scientific institutions during a time when women's roles were largely restricted. It demonstrated the Society’s evolving stance on recognizing and valuing contributions from women in the field of geology.

4. **Encouragement for Future Generations**: Crosfield's election served as an inspiration for future generations of female geologists, showing that it was possible to achieve recognition at the highest levels within the profession despite societal barriers.

Overall, Margaret Crosfield’s election as a Fellow represented both a personal achievement and a broader shift towards inclusivity in scientific societies during the early 20th century.

The funds administered by the Geological Society—Lyell Fund, Murchison Fund, Wollaston Fund, and William Smith Fund—are likely named after prominent figures in geology. This naming convention suggests that these funds are dedicated to supporting activities or initiatives aligned with the legacy and contributions of these individuals to the field of geology.

1. **Lyell Fund**: Named after Charles Lyell, a key figure in establishing modern geology through his principles of uniformitarianism. The fund likely supports research or projects that advance geological understanding in line with Lyell's scientific approach.

2. **Murchison Fund**: Named after Roderick Murchison, known for his work on the Silurian system and contributions to stratigraphy. This fund might support studies related to stratigraphy, paleontology, or other areas where Murchison made significant impacts.

3. **Wollaston Fund**: Named after William Hyde Wollaston, who contributed to mineralogy and geology through discoveries like the mineral wollastonite. The fund could be aimed at supporting research in mineralogy or honoring innovative contributions to geological sciences.

4. **William Smith Fund**: Named after William Smith, often called the "Father of English Geology," known for creating the first nationwide geological map. This fund likely supports mapping projects, educational initiatives, or other activities that promote geological exploration and understanding.

Overall, these funds reflect the Society's mission to advance geological science by honoring past contributions and supporting ongoing research and education in areas significant to these historical figures.

The book "Whatever is Under the Earth: The Geological Society of London 1807 to 2007," authored by G.L. Herries Davies, serves as a comprehensive historical account of the Geological Society of London over two centuries. Published in 2007, it marks the bicentennial of the Society's founding and provides an extensive overview of its development, achievements, and contributions to geology.

The book contributes to our understanding of the Society's history by detailing its origins, growth, and evolution from a small group of enthusiasts into one of the world's leading geological organizations. It highlights key events, milestones, and figures that have shaped the Society over time, offering insights into how it has influenced both national and international geology.

In terms of impact, the book examines the Society's role in advancing geological science through its various activities, including the awarding of medals such as the Wollaston Medal, Murchison Medal, and Lyell Medal. These awards recognize significant contributions to geology, reflecting the Society's commitment to excellence and innovation in the field.

Additionally, the book discusses the funds administered by the Society, like the Lyell Fund, Murchison Fund, and William Smith Fund, which support research and exploration efforts. This underscores the Society's ongoing dedication to fostering scientific inquiry and discovery.

Overall, "Whatever is Under the Earth" provides a detailed narrative of the Geological Society of London's enduring legacy and its pivotal role in shaping geological science from 1807 to 2007.

== Early life ==
Henslow was born at Rochester, Kent, the son of a solicitor John Prentis Henslow, who was the son of John Henslow.

query: What role did John Stevens Henslow play in Charles Darwin's career, and how did he influence Darwin's work on evolution?
reference_contexts:
['John Stevens Henslow (6 February 1796 – 16 May 1861) was an English Anglican priest, botanist and geologist. He is best remembered as friend and mentor to Charles Darwin.


== Early life ==
Henslow was born at Rochester, Kent, the son of a solicitor John Prentis Henslow, who was the son of John Henslow.
Henslow was educated at St. John's College, Cambridge where he graduated as 16th wrangler in 1818, the year in which Adam Sedgwick became Woodwardian Professor of Geology.


== Early career ==
Henslow graduated in 1818. He already had a passion for natural history from his childhood, which largely influenced his career, and he accompanied Sedgwick in 1819 on a tour in the Isle of Wight where he learned his first lessons in geology. He also studied chemistry under Professor James Cumming and mineralogy under Edward Daniel Clarke. In the autumn of 1819 he made valuable observations on the geology of the Isle of Man (Trans. Geol. Soc., 1821) and in 1820 and 1821 he investigated the geology of parts of Anglesey, the results being printed in the first volume of the Transactions of the Cambridge Philosophical Society (1822). The Philosophical Society was founded in November 1819 by a group at Cambridge with Professors Farish, Lee, and Sedgwick and Henslow (at that time not yet a professor). The idea and initial impetus for the society originated from Sedgwick and Henslow.
Meanwhile, Henslow had studied mineralogy with considerable zeal, so that on the death of Clarke he was in 1822 appointed professor of mineralogy in the University of Cambridge. Two years later he took holy orders. Botany, however, had claimed much of his attention, and to this science he became more and more attached, so that he gladly resigned the chair of mineralogy in 1827, two years after becoming professor of botany. As a teacher both in the classroom and in the field he was eminently successful. He was a correspondent of John James Audubon who in 1829 named Henslow's sparrow (Centronyx henslowii) after him.
From 1821 Henslow had begun organising a herbarium of British flora, supplementing his own collecting with a network which expanded over time to include his friends and family, and the botanists William Jackson Hooker and John Hutton Balfour, as well as about 30 of his students. As a mineralogist he had used Haüy's laws of crystallography to analyse complex crystals as transformations of "the primitive form of the species" of crystal, and when he moved to botany in 1825 he sought similarly precise laws to group plant varieties into species, often including as varieties plants that respected taxonomists had ranked as separate species. He followed the understanding of the time that species were fixed as created but could vary within limits, and hoped to analyse these limits of variation. By a method he called "collation", Henslow prepared sheets with several plant specimens, each labelled with the collector, date and place of collection, comparing the specimens to show the variation within the species. His A Catalogue of British Plants was first published in October 1829, and became a set book for his lecture course.
Henslow is remembered as friend and mentor to his pupil Charles Darwin, and for inspiring him with a passion for natural history. The two met in 1828. Earlier that year, Darwin joined the course and along with other students helped to collect plants of Cambridgeshire. Henslow became his tutor, and it was not long before he marked out Darwin as a promising student. In 1830 Henslow experimented on varying the conditions of garden grown wild plants to produce various forms of the plant. In 1835 Henslow published Principles of Descriptive and Physiological Botany as a textbook based on this lecture course.
In the summer of 1831 Henslow was offered a place as naturalist to sail aboard the survey ship HMS Beagle on a two-year voyage to survey South America, but his wife dissuaded him from accepting. Seeing a perfect opportunity for his protégé, Henslow wrote to the ship's captain Robert Fitzroy telling him that Darwin was the ideal man to join the expedition team. During the voyage, Darwin corresponded with Henslow, and collected plants with him in mind. In particular, when first arriving at the Galápagos Islands Darwin noted "I certainly recognize S America in Ornithology, would a botanist?", and went on to collect plant specimens carefully labelled by island and date. He also labelled the mockingbirds he caught, and initially thought these were varieties but while arranging these bird specimens on the last lap of the voyage he began wondering if they could be species, a possibility which would "undermine the stability of Species". Henslow's teaching continued to influence Darwin's work on evolution.
Besides Darwin, other famous students of Henslow included Miles Joseph Berkeley, Cardale Babington, Leonard Jenyns, Richard Thomas Lowe and William Hallowes Miller.']
reference_answer:
John Stevens Henslow played a pivotal role as both a mentor and friend to Charles Darwin, significantly influencing his career and work on evolution. Their relationship began when they met in 1828 at the University of Cambridge, where Henslow was teaching botany. Recognizing Darwin's potential early on, Henslow marked him out as a promising student.

One of Henslow's most significant contributions to Darwin's career was facilitating his participation in the HMS Beagle voyage. Although Henslow himself was offered the position of naturalist aboard the ship, he recommended Darwin for this opportunity instead. This decision proved crucial, as it allowed Darwin to embark on a two-year journey that provided him with invaluable experiences and observations critical to developing his ideas on evolution.

During the voyage, Darwin maintained correspondence with Henslow and collected plant specimens with Henslow's guidance in mind. The influence of Henslow's teaching was evident when Darwin arrived at the Galápagos Islands; he noted similarities between South American and Galápagos species, a reflection of his botanical training under Henslow. This observation led him to question whether certain birds were varieties or distinct species, planting seeds for his later theories on natural selection.

Henslow's approach to botany, which involved analyzing plant variations within species, also shaped Darwin's thinking about variation and the potential for species change over time. Through methods like "collation," Henslow demonstrated how to systematically study and categorize biological diversity, a practice that informed Darwin's scientific methodology.

Overall, John Stevens Henslow was instrumental in shaping Charles Darwin's early career by providing mentorship, facilitating his participation in the Beagle expedition, and influencing his approach to studying natural history. This guidance helped lay the groundwork for Darwin's revolutionary ideas on evolution.

query: Describe the contributions of John Stevens Henslow to botany, particularly his method called "collation" and its purpose.
reference_contexts:
['John Stevens Henslow (6 February 1796 – 16 May 1861) was an English Anglican priest, botanist and geologist. He is best remembered as friend and mentor to Charles Darwin.


== Early life ==
Henslow was born at Rochester, Kent, the son of a solicitor John Prentis Henslow, who was the son of John Henslow.
Henslow was educated at St. John's College, Cambridge where he graduated as 16th wrangler in 1818, the year in which Adam Sedgwick became Woodwardian Professor of Geology.


== Early career ==
Henslow graduated in 1818. He already had a passion for natural history from his childhood, which largely influenced his career, and he accompanied Sedgwick in 1819 on a tour in the Isle of Wight where he learned his first lessons in geology. He also studied chemistry under Professor James Cumming and mineralogy under Edward Daniel Clarke. In the autumn of 1819 he made valuable observations on the geology of the Isle of Man (Trans. Geol. Soc., 1821) and in 1820 and 1821 he investigated the geology of parts of Anglesey, the results being printed in the first volume of the Transactions of the Cambridge Philosophical Society (1822). The Philosophical Society was founded in November 1819 by a group at Cambridge with Professors Farish, Lee, and Sedgwick and Henslow (at that time not yet a professor). The idea and initial impetus for the society originated from Sedgwick and Henslow.
Meanwhile, Henslow had studied mineralogy with considerable zeal, so that on the death of Clarke he was in 1822 appointed professor of mineralogy in the University of Cambridge. Two years later he took holy orders. Botany, however, had claimed much of his attention, and to this science he became more and more attached, so that he gladly resigned the chair of mineralogy in 1827, two years after becoming professor of botany. As a teacher both in the classroom and in the field he was eminently successful. He was a correspondent of John James Audubon who in 1829 named Henslow's sparrow (Centronyx henslowii) after him.
From 1821 Henslow had begun organising a herbarium of British flora, supplementing his own collecting with a network which expanded over time to include his friends and family, and the botanists William Jackson Hooker and John Hutton Balfour, as well as about 30 of his students. As a mineralogist he had used Haüy's laws of crystallography to analyse complex crystals as transformations of "the primitive form of the species" of crystal, and when he moved to botany in 1825 he sought similarly precise laws to group plant varieties into species, often including as varieties plants that respected taxonomists had ranked as separate species. He followed the understanding of the time that species were fixed as created but could vary within limits, and hoped to analyse these limits of variation. By a method he called "collation", Henslow prepared sheets with several plant specimens, each labelled with the collector, date and place of collection, comparing the specimens to show the variation within the species. His A Catalogue of British Plants was first published in October 1829, and became a set book for his lecture course.
Henslow is remembered as friend and mentor to his pupil Charles Darwin, and for inspiring him with a passion for natural history. The two met in 1828. Earlier that year, Darwin joined the course and along with other students helped to collect plants of Cambridgeshire. Henslow became his tutor, and it was not long before he marked out Darwin as a promising student. In 1830 Henslow experimented on varying the conditions of garden grown wild plants to produce various forms of the plant. In 1835 Henslow published Principles of Descriptive and Physiological Botany as a textbook based on this lecture course.
In the summer of 1831 Henslow was offered a place as naturalist to sail aboard the survey ship HMS Beagle on a two-year voyage to survey South America, but his wife dissuaded him from accepting. Seeing a perfect opportunity for his protégé, Henslow wrote to the ship's captain Robert Fitzroy telling him that Darwin was the ideal man to join the expedition team. During the voyage, Darwin corresponded with Henslow, and collected plants with him in mind. In particular, when first arriving at the Galápagos Islands Darwin noted "I certainly recognize S America in Ornithology, would a botanist?", and went on to collect plant specimens carefully labelled by island and date. He also labelled the mockingbirds he caught, and initially thought these were varieties but while arranging these bird specimens on the last lap of the voyage he began wondering if they could be species, a possibility which would "undermine the stability of Species". Henslow's teaching continued to influence Darwin's work on evolution.
Besides Darwin, other famous students of Henslow included Miles Joseph Berkeley, Cardale Babington, Leonard Jenyns, Richard Thomas Lowe and William Hallowes Miller.']
reference_answer:
John Stevens Henslow made significant contributions to botany through both his teaching methods and scientific approaches. One notable contribution was his development of a method known as "collation." This method involved preparing sheets with multiple specimens of the same plant species, each labeled with details such as the collector's name, date, and place of collection. The purpose of collation was to compare these specimens side by side in order to analyze and document the variations within a species.

Henslow used this approach to explore the limits of variation among plants, adhering to the contemporary understanding that while species were considered fixed as created entities, they could exhibit variations within certain boundaries. By systematically documenting these variations, Henslow aimed to establish precise laws for grouping plant varieties into species. This method allowed him and his students to better understand the diversity within plant species and contributed to more accurate botanical classification.

Additionally, Henslow's work in organizing a herbarium of British flora further exemplified his dedication to botany. He expanded this collection through contributions from friends, family, and fellow botanists like William Jackson Hooker and John Hutton Balfour, as well as about 30 of his students. His efforts culminated in the publication of "A Catalogue of British Plants" in October 1829, which became a foundational text for his lecture course.

Overall, Henslow's contributions to botany were marked by his innovative methods and commitment to education, influencing many prominent figures in the field, including Charles Darwin.

query: How did John Stevens Henslow's early education and career choices reflect his passion for natural history, and what positions did he hold at Cambridge University?
reference_contexts:
['John Stevens Henslow (6 February 1796 – 16 May 1861) was an English Anglican priest, botanist and geologist. He is best remembered as friend and mentor to Charles Darwin.

reference_answer:
John Stevens Henslow's early education and career choices were deeply influenced by his passion for natural history. Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge, where he graduated as the 16th wrangler in 1818, Henslow demonstrated an early interest in scientific disciplines. His passion was further nurtured through various educational experiences:

1. **Geology and Mineralogy**: After graduating, Henslow accompanied Adam Sedgwick on a tour of the Isle of Wight in 1819 to learn geology. He also studied chemistry under Professor James Cumming and mineralogy under Edward Daniel Clarke.

2. **Fieldwork and Research**: Henslow conducted significant geological research on the Isle of Man (published in 1821) and parts of Anglesey, contributing valuable observations to the field.

3. **Academic Positions at Cambridge**:
   - In 1822, following Edward Daniel Clarke's death, Henslow was appointed as the professor of mineralogy at the University of Cambridge.
   - Two years later, he took holy orders but continued his academic pursuits in natural history.
   - By 1827, Henslow had shifted his focus to botany and resigned from the chair of mineralogy. He became a professor of botany, where he excelled as both a classroom teacher and field instructor.

4. **Botanical Contributions**: Henslow organized a herbarium of British flora and sought precise laws for grouping plant varieties into species. His work in this area culminated in the publication of "A Catalogue of British Plants" in 1829, which became essential reading for his lecture course.

Through these educational pursuits and academic positions at Cambridge University—professor of mineralogy (1822-1827) and professor of botany (from 1827)—Henslow's career choices clearly reflected his enduring passion for natural history. His influence extended to mentoring notable students, including Charles Darwin, further underscoring his impact on the field.

query: What significant change occurred in Henslow's life when he was appointed as rector of Hitcham, Suffolk in 1837, and how did it impact his involvement with Cambridge University?
reference_contexts:
["== A country clergyman ==
In 1833, Henslow was appointed vicar of Cholsey-cum-Moulsford in Berkshire (now Oxfordshire). He continued to live in Cambridge, only visiting the parish during vacations; he appointed a curate to conduct services and parish business during term-time.
However, his appointment in 1837 to the remunerative Crown living at Hitcham, Suffolk marked a turning-point in his life. This time, in 1839, he moved to the parish, and as rector of Hitcham he lived at the rectory. He worked there, endearing himself to all who knew him, until the end of his life. His energies were devoted to the improvement of his parishioners, but his influence was felt far and wide. Botany at Cambridge suffered, attendance at lectures fell, and we have records of complaints made within the university. Henslow did not resign his chair, and continued to give lectures, set and mark exams, and take part in university affairs. Nevertheless, his influence there was naturally much reduced.
Henslow's work in Hitcham, over and above the normal duties of a Rector, can be summarised as follows:

1. The Parish School and other charities. Hitcham was a poor parish, and most people would have been illiterate. Education had to be paid for, and so Henslow both raised funds and donated his own money to support a school. The school was founded in 1841, and Henslow himself gave a series of volunteer classes on Monday afternoons for some of the older children. The botanical curriculum was printed.The botany taught in this school had effects throughout Britain, because important people at the centre, such as Prince Albert and Lyon Playfair kept in touch and rightly regarded Henslow as an authority on the subject.
2. Adult education in the Village. The Hitcham Labourers' and Mechanics' Horticultural Society was the vehicle used by Henslow to 'improve' the labouring and agricultural workers in the village and its surrounds.  Competitions, shows and excursions were the attractions, and the intent was practical, to improve agriculture by educating the parishioners. Henslow made use of gifts and facilities provided by his friends. Advances such as made by Justus von Liebig in Germany, who began to apply chemistry to the needs of agriculture, had not yet become widely utilised.
3. Museums. The town of Ipswich is twelve miles from Hitcham. As a result of his Cambridge experiences, Henslow believed in the value of museums as vehicles for education. Ipswich Museum was established in 1847 as a natural history museum and owed much to Henslow, who was elected its President in 1850.
Alongside this work he remained an inquiring scientist at heart. In 1843 he discovered nodules of coprolitic origin in the Red Crag at Felixstowe in Suffolk, and two years later he called attention to those also in the Cambridge Greensand and remarked that they might be of use in agriculture. Although Henslow derived no benefit, these discoveries led to the establishment of the phosphate industry in Suffolk and Cambridgeshire; and the works proved lucrative until the introduction of foreign phosphates.
In 1851, Carl Ludwig Blume named a genus of flowering plants belonging to the family Santalaceae, from Indo-China as Henslowia, in honour of Henslow.
Henslow died on 16 May 1861 at Hitcham.


== Family ==
Henslow married Harriet Jenyns (1797–1857), daughter of George Leonard Jenyns and sister of Leonard Jenyns on 16 December 1823. Their eldest daughter Frances Harriet married Joseph Dalton Hooker, and their youngest daughter, Anne, became a botanical artist. Their sons included George Henslow (1835–1925), who became the Royal Horticultural Society's Professor of Botany and the first President of the Churchmen's Union for the Advancement of Liberal Religious Thought."]
reference_answer:
When Henslow was appointed as rector of Hitcham, Suffolk in 1837, a significant change occurred in his life. This appointment marked a turning point because he moved to the parish in 1839 and lived at the rectory there. As rector, he devoted himself to improving his parishioners' lives through various initiatives such as establishing a parish school, promoting adult education, and supporting museums.

This move impacted his involvement with Cambridge University by reducing his influence there. Although Henslow did not resign from his university position, his responsibilities in Hitcham meant that attendance at his lectures fell, and he faced complaints within the university regarding his reduced presence. Despite continuing to give lectures, set exams, and participate in university affairs, his focus shifted significantly towards his parish work, leading to a natural decline in his influence at Cambridge.

query: Describe the role of the Hitcham Labourers' and Mechanics' Horticultural Society in Henslow's efforts to improve agriculture and education among parishioners.

reference_answer:
The Hitcham Labourers' and Mechanics' Horticultural Society played a significant role in Henslow's efforts to enhance both agriculture and education among the parishioners of Hitcham. This society served as a practical vehicle for "improving" the laboring and agricultural workers within the village and its surrounding areas. The primary intent behind this initiative was educational, aiming to elevate agricultural practices by educating the local community.

Henslow utilized various methods through the society to engage parishioners in learning and development. These included organizing competitions, shows, and excursions that were designed not only as attractions but also as practical means of imparting knowledge about better agricultural techniques. The society provided a platform for hands-on learning experiences, which was crucial at a time when theoretical advances in agriculture, such as those made by Justus von Liebig in Germany, had yet to be widely adopted.

Moreover, Henslow leveraged gifts and facilities from his friends to support the activities of the society, thereby enriching the resources available for educational purposes. Through these efforts, he aimed to foster a more informed and skilled agricultural workforce, ultimately contributing to the improvement of local agriculture in Hitcham. The society thus became an integral part of Henslow's broader mission to uplift his parishioners through education and practical application of knowledge.

reference_answer:

query: Which of John Stevens Henslow's daughters became a botanical artist, and who did his eldest daughter Frances Harriet marry?
reference_contexts:
['== Family ==
Henslow married Harriet Jenyns (1797–1857), daughter of George Leonard Jenyns and sister of Leonard Jenyns on 16 December 1823. Their eldest daughter Frances Harriet married Joseph Dalton Hooker, and their youngest daughter, Anne, became a botanical artist. Their sons included George Henslow (1835–1925), who became the Royal Horticultural Society's Professor of Botany and the first President of the Churchmen's Union for the Advancement of Liberal Religious Thought.


== Selected publications ==

reference_answer:
Two publications by John Stevens Henslow that were reissued by Cambridge University Press in 2009 are:

1. "A Syllabus of a Course of Lectures on Mineralogy" (1823), with the ISBN number 978-1-108-00201-1.
2. "The Principles of Descriptive and Physiological Botany" (1835), with the ISBN number 978-1-108-00186-1.

These reissues are part of a series that includes several other works by Henslow, reflecting his contributions to botany and mineralogy.

query: What significant contributions did Adam Sedgwick make to the geological timescale, and how were these periods named?
reference_contexts:
['Adam Sedgwick FRS (; 22 March 1785 – 27 January 1873) was a British geologist and Anglican priest, one of the founders of modern geology.  He proposed the Cambrian and Devonian period of the geological timescale. Based on work which he did on Welsh rock strata, he proposed the Cambrian period in 1835, in a joint publication in which Roderick Murchison also proposed the Silurian period.  Later in 1840, to resolve what later became known as the Great Devonian Controversy about rocks near the boundary between the Silurian and Carboniferous periods, he and Murchison proposed the Devonian period.
Though he had guided the young Charles Darwin in his early study of geology and continued to be on friendly terms, Sedgwick was an opponent of Darwin's theory of evolution by means of natural selection.
He strongly opposed the admission of women to the University of Cambridge, in one conversation describing aspiring female students as "nasty forward minxes."


== Life and career ==
Sedgwick was born in Dent, Yorkshire, the third child of an Anglican vicar. He was educated at Sedbergh School and Trinity College, Cambridge.
He studied mathematics and theology, and obtained his BA (5th Wrangler) from the University of Cambridge in 1808 and his MA in 1811. On 20 July 1817 he was ordained a deacon, then a year later he was ordained as a priest. His academic mentors at Cambridge were Thomas Jones and John Dawson. He became a Fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge and Woodwardian Professor of Geology at Cambridge from 1818, holding the chair until his death in 1873. His biography in the Cambridge Alumni database says that upon his acceptance of the position, Sedgwick had no working knowledge of geology. An 1851 portrait of Sedgwick by William Boxall hangs in Trinity's collection.
Sedgwick studied the geology of the British Isles and Europe. He founded the system for the classification of Cambrian rocks and with Roderick Murchison worked out the order of the Carboniferous and underlying Devonian strata. These studies were mostly carried out in the 1830s. The investigations into the Devonian meant that Sedgwick was involved with Murchison in a vigorous debate with Henry De la Beche, in what became known as the great Devonian controversy.
He also employed John William Salter for a short time in arranging the fossils in the Woodwardian Museum at Cambridge, and whom accompanied the professor on several geological expeditions (1842–1845) into Wales. John Ruthven, with whom Sedgwick has a room at Kendal museum co-named after him, also frequently accompanied Sedgwick in Wales and beyond.
Sedgwick investigated the phenomena of metamorphism and concretion, and was the first to distinguish clearly between stratification, jointing, and slaty cleavage. He was elected to Fellow of the Royal Society on 1 February 1821. In 1844, he was elected a Foreign Honorary Member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He was president of the Geological Society of London.


== Geological views and evolution ==

The Church of England, by no means a fundamentalist or evangelical church, encloses a wide range of beliefs. During Sedgwick's life there developed something of a chasm between the conservative high church believers and the liberal wing. After simmering for some years, the publication of Essays and Reviews by liberal churchmen in 1860 pinpointed the differences. In all this, Sedgwick, whose science and faith were intertwined in a natural theology, was definitely on the conservative side, and extremely outspoken about it. He told the February 1830 meeting of the Geological Society of London:

No opinion can be heretical, but that which is not true.... Conflicting falsehoods we can comprehend; but truths can never war against each other. I affirm, therefore, that we have nothing to fear from the results of our enquiries, provided they be followed in the laborious but secure road of honest induction. In this way we may rest assured that we shall never arrive at conclusions opposed to any truth, either physical or moral, from whatever source that truth may be derived ...
As a geologist in the mid-1820s he supported William Buckland's interpretation of certain superficial deposits, particularly loose rocks and gravel, as "diluvium" relating to worldwide floods, and in 1825 he published two papers identifying these as due to a "great irregular inundation" from the "waters of a general deluge", Noah's flood. Sedgwick's subsequent investigations and discussions with continental geologists persuaded him that this was problematic.']
reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick made several significant contributions to the geological timescale through his work on rock strata. He proposed two major geological periods:

1. **Cambrian Period**: In 1835, based on his studies of Welsh rock strata, Sedgwick proposed the Cambrian period in a joint publication with Roderick Murchison. This proposal was part of their efforts to classify and understand the sequence of ancient rocks.

2. **Devonian Period**: To address what became known as the Great Devonian Controversy regarding the classification of rocks near the boundary between the Silurian and Carboniferous periods, Sedgwick, along with Murchison, proposed the Devonian period in 1840. This helped clarify the geological timeline by distinguishing this new period.

These contributions were pivotal in establishing a more structured understanding of Earth's geological history. The names "Cambrian" and "Devonian" are derived from geographical regions associated with these periods: Cambria is an old name for Wales, where Sedgwick conducted much of his research on the Cambrian rocks; Devonian is named after Devonshire (now Devon), a county in England, reflecting the region's geological significance during this period.

reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick and Charles Darwin had a complex relationship characterized by both mentorship and ideological differences. Initially, Sedgwick played an influential role in guiding Darwin's early studies in geology. As a professor at the University of Cambridge, Sedgwick was one of Darwin’s mentors during his time as a student there. Despite their differing views on evolution later in life, they maintained friendly terms.

Sedgwick was a prominent figure in the field of geology and contributed significantly to the geological timescale by proposing the Cambrian and Devonian periods. However, he held conservative religious beliefs that were intertwined with his scientific work, adhering to natural theology—a perspective that sought to understand God's design through nature.

In contrast, Charles Darwin developed a theory of evolution by means of natural selection, which challenged traditional views on creation and was seen as controversial at the time. Sedgwick opposed Darwin’s evolutionary ideas, reflecting his conservative stance within the Church of England. Despite their differing perspectives on evolution, Sedgwick's early mentorship played an important role in shaping Darwin's scientific career.

Their relationship highlights a broader historical context where science and religion often intersected and sometimes conflicted during the 19th century. While they disagreed on fundamental issues like evolution, their personal interactions remained amicable, illustrating how intellectual discourse can persist despite profound disagreements.

query: How did Adam Sedgwick's religious beliefs influence his scientific work and public statements during his career?

reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick's religious beliefs significantly influenced both his scientific work and public statements throughout his career. As a devout Anglican priest, he integrated his faith with his scientific pursuits, adhering to the principles of natural theology, which sought to understand God through the study of nature.

1. **Natural Theology**: Sedgwick believed that science and religion were not in conflict but rather complementary. He held that truths derived from scientific inquiry could never contradict moral or physical truths, as he expressed in his 1830 address to the Geological Society of London. This perspective guided his approach to geology, where he sought to uncover natural laws that aligned with his religious beliefs.

2. **Initial Support for Diluvialism**: In the mid-1820s, Sedgwick supported William Buckland's interpretation of certain geological formations as "diluvium," attributing them to a global flood akin to Noah's Flood described in the Bible. This view was consistent with his religious beliefs at the time and reflected an attempt to reconcile scientific observations with scriptural accounts.

3. **Shift from Diluvialism**: Over time, Sedgwick's interactions with continental geologists led him to reconsider this interpretation. He recognized that attributing geological formations solely to a biblical flood was problematic, indicating a willingness to adapt his views in light of new evidence while still maintaining his faith-based perspective on the natural world.

4. **Conservative Religious Stance**: During a period when debates about science and religion were intensifying within the Church of England, Sedgwick aligned with the conservative wing. He opposed liberal theological interpretations that emerged from works like "Essays and Reviews" in 1860. His outspoken nature on these matters reflected his commitment to maintaining traditional religious views alongside scientific inquiry.

5. **Opposition to Evolution**: Despite mentoring Charles Darwin, Sedgwick was a vocal opponent of Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection. This opposition can be seen as consistent with his conservative theological stance, which likely viewed evolutionary theory as conflicting with the biblical account of creation.

Overall, Adam Sedgwick's religious beliefs were deeply intertwined with his scientific work and public statements, influencing how he interpreted geological evidence and engaged in broader debates about science and religion during his lifetime.

query: How did Sedgwick's views on geology change after his visit to the Scottish Highlands with Roderick Murchison, and what external influences contributed to this shift?
reference_contexts:
['Sedgwick's subsequent investigations and discussions with continental geologists persuaded him that this was problematic. In early 1827, after spending several weeks in Paris, he visited geological features in the Scottish Highlands with Roderick Murchison. He later wrote "If I have been converted in part from the diluvian theory...it was...by my own gradual improved experience, and by communicating with those about me. Perhaps I may date my change of mind (at least in part) from our journey in the Highlands, where there are so many indications of local diluvial operations.... Humboldt ridiculed [the doctrine] beyond measure when I met him in Paris. Prévost lectured against it."  In response to Charles Lyell's 1830 publication, Principles of Geology, which is known for promoting uniformitarian geology Sedgwick talked of floods at various dates, then on 18 February 1831 when retiring from the Presidency of the Geological Society he recanted his former belief in Buckland's theory.
He strongly believed that species of organisms originated in a succession of Divine creative acts throughout the long expanse of history. Any form of development that denied a direct creative action smacked as materialistic and amoral. For Sedgwick, moral truths (the obtainment of which separates man from beast) were to be distinguished from physical truths, and to combine these or blur them together could only lead to disastrous consequences. In fact, one's own hope for immortality may ultimately rest on it.
He stated in 1830 that scriptural geologists proposed "a deformed progeny of heretical and fantastical conclusions, by which sober philosophy has been put to open shame, and sometimes even the charities of life have been exposed to violation." In 1834 he continued, "They have committed the folly and SIN of dogmatizing," having "sinned against plain sense," and "of writing mischievous nonsense," "Their eyes cannot bear to look upon" truth and suppose an "ignorant and dishonest" theory.  They show "bigotry and ignorance," of nature's laws and natural phenomena. Henry Cole then responded in 1834 in a 136-page "letter," Popular Geology Subversive of Divine Revelation. He referred to Sedgwick's ideas as "unscriptural and anti-Christian," "scripture-defying", "revelation-subverting," and "baseless speculations and self-contradictions," which were "impious and infidel".
While he became increasingly Evangelical with age, he strongly supported advances in geology against conservative churchmen. At the September 1844 British Association for the Advancement of Science meeting at York he achieved national celebrity for his reply defending modern geology against an attack by the Dean of York, the Reverend William Cockburn, who described it as unscriptural. The entire chapter house of the cathedral refused to sit down with Sedgwick, and he was opposed by conservative papers including The Times, but his courage was hailed by the full spectrum of the liberal press, and the confrontation was a key moment in the battle over relations between Scripture and science.

When Robert Chambers anonymously published his own theory of universal evolutionism as his "development hypothesis" in the book Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation published in October 1844 to immediate popular success, Sedgwick's many friends urged him to respond. Like other eminent scientists he initially ignored the book, but the subject kept recurring and he then read it carefully and made a withering attack on the book in the July 1845 edition of the Edinburgh Review. Vestiges "comes before [its readers] with a bright, polished, and many-coloured surface, and the serpent coils a false philosophy, and asks them to stretch out their hands and pluck the forbidden fruit", he wrote in his review. Accepting the arguments in Vestiges was akin to falling from grace and away from God's favour.
He lashed out at the book in a letter to Charles Lyell, bemoaning the consequences of it conclusions. "...If the book be true, the labours of sober induction are in vain; religion is a lie; human law is a mass of folly, and a base injustice; morality is moonshine; our labours for the black people of Africa were works of madmen; and man and woman are only better beasts!" Later, Sedgwick added a long preface to the 5th edition of his Discourse on the Studies of the University of Cambridge (1850), including a lengthy attack on Vestiges and theories of development in general.
Charles Darwin was one of his geology students in 1831, and accompanied him on a field trip to Wales that summer. The two kept up a correspondence while Darwin was on the Beagle expedition, and afterwards.']
reference_answer:
Sedgwick's views on geology underwent a significant transformation following his visit to the Scottish Highlands with Roderick Murchison in early 1827. Initially adhering to the diluvian theory, which posited that geological features were primarily shaped by catastrophic events like Noah's Flood, Sedgwick began to reconsider this stance during their journey through the Highlands. The region presented numerous indications of local diluvial operations, prompting him to question his previous beliefs.

Several external influences contributed to this shift in perspective:

1. **Interactions with Continental Geologists**: During a visit to Paris before heading to Scotland, Sedgwick engaged in discussions with prominent geologists like Alexander von Humboldt and Louis Prévost. Humboldt ridiculed the diluvian theory, while Prévost lectured against it, both of whom likely influenced Sedgwick's growing skepticism towards his earlier views.

2. **Charles Lyell’s Uniformitarianism**: The publication of Charles Lyell's "Principles of Geology" in 1830 further impacted Sedgwick. Lyell promoted uniformitarian geology, which argued that the Earth was shaped by continuous and consistent processes over long periods rather than sudden catastrophic events. This perspective resonated with Sedgwick, leading him to publicly recant his former belief in Buckland's diluvian theory on February 18, 1831.

3. **Personal Reflections and Experiences**: Sedgwick himself noted that his change of mind was partly due to "gradual improved experience" and discussions with colleagues. His journey through the Scottish Highlands served as a pivotal moment for reevaluating geological theories based on direct observations.

Overall, Sedgwick's shift from diluvialism to a more nuanced understanding of geology was influenced by both intellectual exchanges with other scientists and his own empirical experiences in the field.

"...If the book be true, the labours of sober induction are in vain; religion is a lie; human law is a mass of folly, and a base injustice; morality is moonshine; our labours for the black people of Africa were works of madmen; and man and woman are only better beasts!" Later, Sedgwick added a long preface to the 5th edition of his Discourse on the Studies of the University of Cambridge (1850), including a lengthy attack on Vestiges and theories of development in general.
Charles Darwin was one of his geology students in 1831, and accompanied him on a field trip to Wales that summer. The two kept up a correspondence while Darwin was on the Beagle expedition, and afterwards.']
reference_answer:
In 1830, Adam Sedgwick criticized scriptural geologists for proposing what he described as "a deformed progeny of heretical and fantastical conclusions." He believed that these ideas had put sober philosophy to shame and sometimes even violated the charities of life. By 1834, his criticisms intensified; he accused them of committing a "folly and SIN" by dogmatizing and sinning against plain sense. Sedgwick described their writings as "mischievous nonsense," suggesting they were unable or unwilling to confront truth due to ignorance and dishonesty. He characterized their approach as showing "bigotry and ignorance" regarding nature's laws and natural phenomena.

Sedgwick perceived the scriptural geologists' approach as fundamentally flawed because it involved a rigid adherence to dogma that ignored empirical evidence and scientific reasoning. He believed they were blinded by their own biases, which prevented them from accepting truths about the natural world. This perspective was in stark contrast to his support for advances in geology based on observation and evidence, even when these findings challenged traditional scriptural interpretations. Sedgwick's criticisms reflect his belief that conflating moral and physical truths could lead to disastrous consequences, undermining both scientific understanding and religious faith.

query: Describe Sedgwick's reaction to Robert Chambers' "Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation" and explain his concerns about its implications for religion and morality.
reference_contexts:
['Sedgwick's subsequent investigations and discussions with continental geologists persuaded him that this was problematic. In early 1827, after spending several weeks in Paris, he visited geological features in the Scottish Highlands with Roderick Murchison. He later wrote "If I have been converted in part from the diluvian theory...it was...by my own gradual improved experience, and by communicating with those about me. Perhaps I may date my change of mind (at least in part) from our journey in the Highlands, where there are so many indications of local diluvial operations.... Humboldt ridiculed [the doctrine] beyond measure when I met him in Paris. Prévost lectured against it."  In response to Charles Lyell's 1830 publication, Principles of Geology, which is known for promoting uniformitarian geology Sedgwick talked of floods at various dates, then on 18 February 1831 when retiring from the Presidency of the Geological Society he recanted his former belief in Buckland's theory.
He strongly believed that species of organisms originated in a succession of Divine creative acts throughout the long expanse of history. Any form of development that denied a direct creative action smacked as materialistic and amoral. For Sedgwick, moral truths (the obtainment of which separates man from beast) were to be distinguished from physical truths, and to combine these or blur them together could only lead to disastrous consequences. In fact, one's own hope for immortality may ultimately rest on it.
He stated in 1830 that scriptural geologists proposed "a deformed progeny of heretical and fantastical conclusions, by which sober philosophy has been put to open shame, and sometimes even the charities of life have been exposed to violation." In 1834 he continued, "They have committed the folly and SIN of dogmatizing," having "sinned against plain sense," and "of writing mischievous nonsense," "Their eyes cannot bear to look upon" truth and suppose an "ignorant and dishonest" theory.  They show "bigotry and ignorance," of nature's laws and natural phenomena. Henry Cole then responded in 1834 in a 136-page "letter," Popular Geology Subversive of Divine Revelation. He referred to Sedgwick's ideas as "unscriptural and anti-Christian," "scripture-defying", "revelation-subverting," and "baseless speculations and self-contradictions," which were "impious and infidel".
While he became increasingly Evangelical with age, he strongly supported advances in geology against conservative churchmen. At the September 1844 British Association for the Advancement of Science meeting at York he achieved national celebrity for his reply defending modern geology against an attack by the Dean of York, the Reverend William Cockburn, who described it as unscriptural. The entire chapter house of the cathedral refused to sit down with Sedgwick, and he was opposed by conservative papers including The Times, but his courage was hailed by the full spectrum of the liberal press, and the confrontation was a key moment in the battle over relations between Scripture and science.

When Robert Chambers anonymously published his own theory of universal evolutionism as his "development hypothesis" in the book Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation published in October 1844 to immediate popular success, Sedgwick's many friends urged him to respond. Like other eminent scientists he initially ignored the book, but the subject kept recurring and he then read it carefully and made a withering attack on the book in the July 1845 edition of the Edinburgh Review. Vestiges "comes before [its readers] with a bright, polished, and many-coloured surface, and the serpent coils a false philosophy, and asks them to stretch out their hands and pluck the forbidden fruit", he wrote in his review. Accepting the arguments in Vestiges was akin to falling from grace and away from God's favour.
He lashed out at the book in a letter to Charles Lyell, bemoaning the consequences of it conclusions. "...If the book be true, the labours of sober induction are in vain; religion is a lie; human law is a mass of folly, and a base injustice; morality is moonshine; our labours for the black people of Africa were works of madmen; and man and woman are only better beasts!" Later, Sedgwick added a long preface to the 5th edition of his Discourse on the Studies of the University of Cambridge (1850), including a lengthy attack on Vestiges and theories of development in general.
Charles Darwin was one of his geology students in 1831, and accompanied him on a field trip to Wales that summer. The two kept up a correspondence while Darwin was on the Beagle expedition, and afterwards.']
reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick had a vehemently negative reaction to Robert Chambers' book "Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation." Initially, like many eminent scientists of his time, he ignored the publication. However, as discussions around it persisted, he eventually read the book carefully and responded with strong criticism.

Sedgwick's primary concern was that accepting the ideas presented in "Vestiges" would undermine fundamental aspects of society and belief systems. He believed that if Chambers' theory of universal evolutionism were true, it would render the efforts of scientific inquiry through sober induction meaningless. More profoundly, Sedgwick feared that such a perspective would challenge the very foundations of religion, suggesting that religious beliefs were false.

He also argued that accepting evolutionary ideas as proposed in "Vestiges" would lead to moral and legal chaos. According to Sedgwick, human laws would be seen as foolish and unjust, morality would become illusory ("moonshine"), and efforts such as those aimed at improving the lives of African people would be deemed misguided actions by "madmen." In his view, accepting these ideas would reduce humans to being no better than animals.

Sedgwick's critique extended beyond just a scientific disagreement; he saw it as an existential threat to religious faith and moral order. He expressed these concerns in various platforms, including a scathing review in the Edinburgh Review and a letter to Charles Lyell, where he lamented the potential consequences of Chambers' conclusions. His opposition was rooted in his belief that such theories were not only scientifically flawed but also morally and spiritually dangerous.

query: How did Adam Sedgwick's views on Charles Darwin's "On the Origin of Species" differ from his perspective on Vestiges, and what specific criticisms did he express about Darwin's methodology?
reference_contexts:
['Later, Sedgwick added a long preface to the 5th edition of his Discourse on the Studies of the University of Cambridge (1850), including a lengthy attack on Vestiges and theories of development in general.
Charles Darwin was one of his geology students in 1831, and accompanied him on a field trip to Wales that summer. The two kept up a correspondence while Darwin was on the Beagle expedition, and afterwards.  However, Sedgwick never accepted the case for evolution made in On the Origin of Species in 1859 any more than he did that in  Vestiges in 1844.  In response to receiving and reading Darwin's book, he wrote to Darwin saying:

If I did not think you a good tempered & truth loving man I should not tell you that... I have read your book with more pain than pleasure. Parts of it I admired greatly; parts I laughed at till my sides were almost sore; other parts I read with absolute sorrow; because I think them utterly false & grievously mischievous – You have deserted—after a start in that tram-road of all solid physical truth—the true method of induction—& started up a machinery as wild I think as Bishop Wilkins's locomotive that was to sail with us to the Moon. Many of your wide conclusions are based upon assumptions which can neither be proved nor disproved. Why then express them in the language & arrangements of philosophical induction?
Sedgwick regarded natural selection as

but a secondary consequence of supposed, or known, primary facts. Development is a better word because more close to the cause of the fact. For you do not deny causation. I call (in the abstract) causation the will of God: & I can prove that He acts for the good of His creatures. He also acts by laws which we can study &  comprehend—Acting by law, & under what is called final cause, comprehends, I think, your whole principle ...
He emphasised his distinction between the moral and physical aspects of life, "There is a moral or metaphysical part of nature as well as a physical. A man who denies this is deep in the mire of folly". If humanity broke this distinction it "would suffer a damage that might brutalize it—& sink the human race into a lower grade of degradation than any into which it has fallen since its written records tell us of its history".
In a letter to another correspondent, Sedgwick was even harsher on Darwin's book, calling it "utterly false" and writing that "It repudiates all reasoning from final causes; and seems to shut the door on any view (however feeble) of the God of Nature as manifested in His works. From first to last it is a dish of rank materialism cleverly cooked and served up".
Despite this difference of opinion, the two men remained friendly until Sedgwick's death. In contrast to Sedgwick, liberal church members (who included biologists such as George Rolleston, William Henry Flower and William Kitchen Parker) were usually comfortable with evolution.


== Links and opposition to slavery ==
As a co-trustee of the will of Ann Sill, an owner of slaves in plantations in Jamaica, in 1835 Sedgwick was awarded half of £3,783 in compensation for 174 slaves, following the abolition of slavery by the British government. Sedgwick is listed in the University College London database, Centre for the Study of the Legacies of British Slave Ownership, as being an awardee in receipt of £3,783 1s 8d on 8 February 1836 for "174 Enslaved". He was one of 46,000 people paid compensation during the abolition of slavery in the United Kingdom. A liberal Whig in politics, Sedgwick had long been a passionate supporter of abolition. In a letter to Bishop Wilberforce, dated July 16, 1848, Sedgwick wrote of signing a petition against the slave trade while he was a child—the first "political act of [his] life"—after his father had shown him "ugly pictures of the horrors of slavery".']
reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick's views on Charles Darwin's "On the Origin of Species" were similar to his perspective on Vestiges in that he rejected both works' theories of evolution. However, his criticism of Darwin was more detailed and focused specifically on Darwin's methodology.

Sedgwick criticized Darwin for abandoning what he considered the true method of induction—a systematic approach to scientific inquiry based on observation and evidence—by introducing ideas that Sedgwick viewed as speculative and unprovable. He compared Darwin’s theoretical machinery unfavorably to Bishop Wilkins's fanciful idea of a lunar locomotive, suggesting it was equally unrealistic.

Sedgwick argued that many of Darwin's conclusions were based on assumptions that could neither be proven nor disproven, which he found problematic when expressed in the language and structure of philosophical induction. He believed that natural selection, as proposed by Darwin, was merely a secondary consequence rather than a primary cause of development. Sedgwick preferred to attribute causation to divine will, emphasizing his belief in God's role in acting for the good of His creatures through comprehensible laws.

Overall, while Sedgwick rejected both Vestiges and "On the Origin of Species," his critique of Darwin was more focused on what he saw as methodological flaws and a departure from established scientific principles. Despite these differences, Sedgwick maintained a friendly relationship with Darwin until his death.

reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick reconciled his scientific beliefs with his religious convictions by maintaining a clear distinction between moral/metaphysical aspects of nature and physical ones. He viewed the concept of development as more aligned with causation than natural selection, which he saw as merely a secondary consequence of primary facts. For Sedgwick, causation was synonymous with divine will—specifically, "the will of God"—and he believed that God acted for the good of His creatures through comprehensible laws and final causes.

Sedgwick emphasized that understanding nature required acknowledging both its physical and moral dimensions. He argued that denying this dual aspect would lead to a degradation of humanity, suggesting that scientific inquiry should not dismiss metaphysical or theological considerations. In his critique of Darwin's "On the Origin of Species," Sedgwick expressed concern that Darwin's ideas repudiated reasoning from final causes and seemed to exclude any view of God in nature, which he saw as an essential component of understanding natural phenomena.

Despite rejecting Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection, Sedgwick maintained a friendly relationship with Darwin, indicating his ability to separate personal relationships from scientific disagreements. His approach reflects an attempt to integrate his religious beliefs with his scientific work, emphasizing that the study of nature should include both empirical investigation and theological reflection.
