reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick's political stance on slavery was firmly against it, as evidenced by his actions and beliefs throughout his life. Despite receiving compensation for slaves following their emancipation—a common practice at the time—Sedgwick had long been a passionate supporter of abolition.

His commitment to ending slavery manifested early in his life when he signed a petition against the slave trade while still a child. This act was described as the first "political act" of his life, spurred by his father showing him "ugly pictures of the horrors of slavery." This early action demonstrated Sedgwick's deep-seated opposition to slavery and set the tone for his lifelong advocacy.

As an adult, Sedgwick maintained a liberal Whig political stance, which aligned with his abolitionist views. His involvement as a co-trustee in receiving compensation for slaves was more a reflection of legal obligations following the British government's abolition of slavery rather than support for the institution itself. Overall, Sedgwick's actions and beliefs consistently reflected his opposition to slavery and his commitment to its abolition.

query: In what year was the Sedgwick Museum completed and opened, and who played a key role in its establishment?
reference_contexts:
['== Legacy ==

The Sedgwick Club, the oldest student-run geological society in the world, was set up in honour of him in 1880.
On the death of Sedgwick it was decided that his memorial should take the form of a new and larger museum. There was brief, later discarded, talk of opening a Sedgwick youth summer programme. Hitherto the geological collections had been placed in the Woodwardian Museum in Cockerell's Building. Through the energy of Professor T. McK. Hughes (successor to Sedgwick) the new building, termed the Sedgwick Museum, was completed and opened in 1903.
In 1865, the University of Cambridge received from A. A. Van Sittart the sum of 500 pounds sterling "for the purpose of encouraging the study of geology among the resident members of the university, and in honour of the Rev. Adam Sedgwick". Thus was founded the Sedgwick Prize to be given every third year for the best essay on some geological subject. The first Sedgwick Prize was awarded in 1873 and has continued into the 21st century.
To celebrate the bicentenary of Sedgwick's birth a geological trail was created near Dent, the village where he was born and developed his passion for geology (amongst other things). The Sedgwick Trail follows the River Clough, highlighting rock features and exploring the Dent Fault.
Mount Sedgwick in British Columbia, Canada, was officially named after him in 1951.


== Notes ==


== References ==
Chisholm, Hugh, ed. (1911). "Sedgwick, Adam" . Encyclopædia Britannica. Vol. 24 (11th ed.). Cambridge University Press. pp. 557–558.
J.W. Clark and T.M. Hughes, The Life and Letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick, Cambridge University Press, 1890, vols. 1–2. (Reissued by Cambridge University Press, 2010. ISBN 978-1-108-01831-9)
Dictionary of Scientific Biography, Charles Scribner's Sons: 1970–1990; vol. 12, pp. 275–279.
A Biographical Dictionary of Scientists, Williams, T. I., Ed., Wiley, 1969, pp. 467–468.
Isaac Asimov, I. Asimov's Biographical Encyclopedia of Science and Technology (2nd Ed.), Doubleday: 1982, p. 299.
Quart. J. Geol. Soc., 1873, 29, pp. xxx–xxxix.
Bonney, Thomas George (1889). "Sedgwick, Adam" . In Stephen, Leslie (ed.). Dictionary of National Biography. Vol. 17. London: Smith, Elder & Co. pp. 179–182.
"Adam Sedgwick – Geologist and Dalesman" Colin Speakman Broad Oak Press 1982.
"Adam Sedgwick's Dent"  A facsimile reprint of 'A Memorial by the Trustees of Cowgill Chapel (1868) and 'Supplement to the Memorial (1870) by Adam Sedgwick with introduction by David Boulton Hollett, Sedbergh and David Boulton Dent 1984.
"A Discourse on the Studies of the University" Adam Sedgwick The Victorian Library, Leicester University Press 1969
Browne, E. Janet (1995), Charles Darwin: vol. 1 Voyaging, London: Jonathan Cape, ISBN 1-84413-314-1
Herbert, Sandra (1991), "Charles Darwin as a prospective geological author", British Journal for the History of Science, vol. 24, no. 2, pp. 159–192, doi:10.1017/s0007087400027060, S2CID 143748414, archived from the original on 8 February 2009, retrieved 24 January 2009
Secord, James A. (2000), Victorian Sensation: the extraordinary publication, reception, and secret authorship of Vestiges of the natural history of creation, Chicago: University of Chicago Press, ISBN 0-226-74411-6


== External links ==

Sedgwick Museum, Cambridge
Works by or about Adam Sedgwick at the Internet Archive
The life and letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick Vol.1 by J.W.Clark, 1890
The life and letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick Vol.2 by J.W.Clark, 1890
Obituary in: "Obituary" . Popular Science Monthly. Vol. 2. April 1873.']
reference_answer: The Sedgwick Museum was completed and opened in the year 1903. A key figure in its establishment was Professor T. McK. Hughes, who succeeded Adam Sedgwick and played an instrumental role through his energy and efforts to bring the new building project to fruition. The museum was named in honor of Adam Sedgwick, reflecting his significant contributions to geology and education at the University of Cambridge.

reference_answer:
The Sedgwick Prize was established by A. A. Van Sittart in 1865 with the specific purpose of encouraging the study of geology among resident members of the University of Cambridge. This initiative was made in honor of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick, a prominent figure in the field of geology. The prize is awarded every third year for the best essay on some geological subject, highlighting its role as an academic incentive and recognition within the university's geological community.

The significance of the Sedgwick Prize lies not only in its encouragement of scholarly work but also in its longevity and prestige. Since its inception, it has continued to be awarded into the 21st century, marking it as a longstanding tradition that underscores the importance of geology at Cambridge University. The first award was given in 1873, further cementing its place as an enduring academic accolade.

Overall, the Sedgwick Prize serves both as a tribute to Adam Sedgwick's contributions to geology and as a means to foster ongoing research and excellence within the field among students at the University of Cambridge.

On the death of Sedgwick it was decided that his memorial should take the form of a new and larger museum. There was brief, later discarded, talk of opening a Sedgwick youth summer programme. Hughes (successor to Sedgwick) the new building, termed the Sedgwick Museum, was completed and opened in 1903.
In 1865, the University of Cambridge received from A. A. Van Sittart the sum of 500 pounds sterling "for the purpose of encouraging the study of geology among the resident members of the university, and in honour of the Rev. Adam Sedgwick". Thus was founded the Sedgwick Prize to be given every third year for the best essay on some geological subject. The first Sedgwick Prize was awarded in 1873 and has continued into the 21st century.
To celebrate the bicentenary of Sedgwick's birth a geological trail was created near Dent, the village where he was born and developed his passion for geology (amongst other things). The Sedgwick Trail follows the River Clough, highlighting rock features and exploring the Dent Fault.
Mount Sedgwick in British Columbia, Canada, was officially named after him in 1951.


== Notes ==

reference_answer:
Mount Sedgwick in British Columbia, Canada, holds significance as a geographical feature named in honor of Adam Sedgwick, a prominent geologist. The mountain was officially named after him in 1951 to recognize his contributions to the field of geology and his influence on geological studies.

Adam Sedgwick was an influential figure in the development of geology during the 19th century. He played a crucial role in advancing geological understanding through his work, teachings, and mentorship. His legacy includes founding the Sedgwick Club, which is the oldest student-run geological society in the world, established in 1880 to honor him.

Additionally, Sedgwick's impact extended beyond academia; he inspired various memorials and initiatives that continue to celebrate his contributions. For instance, the Sedgwick Museum at the University of Cambridge was completed in 1903 as a memorial to him, housing geological collections previously placed in the Woodwardian Museum. Furthermore, the Sedgwick Prize, established in 1865 with funds from A.A. Van Sittart, is awarded every third year for outstanding essays on geological subjects.

The naming of Mount Sedgwick serves as a lasting tribute to his legacy and influence in geology, commemorating his life's work and passion for understanding the Earth's geological features.

query: What was the original title of Charles Darwin's book published in 1839, and how did its title evolve over time?
reference_contexts:
['The Voyage of the Beagle is the title most commonly given to the book written by Charles Darwin and published in 1839 as his Journal and Remarks, bringing him considerable fame and respect. This was the third volume of The Narrative of the Voyages of H.M. Ships Adventure and Beagle, the other volumes of which were written or edited by the commanders of the ships. Journal and Remarks covers Darwin's part in the second survey expedition of the ship HMS Beagle. Due to the popularity of Darwin's account, the publisher reissued it later in 1839 as Darwin's Journal of Researches, and the revised second edition published in 1845 used this title. A republication of the book in 1905 introduced the title The Voyage of the "Beagle", by which it is now best known.

Beagle sailed from Plymouth Sound on 27 December 1831 under the command of Captain Robert FitzRoy. While the expedition was originally planned to last two years, it lasted almost five—Beagle did not return until 2 October 1836. Darwin spent most of this time exploring on land (three years and three months on land; 18 months at sea). The book is a vivid travel memoir as well as a detailed scientific field journal covering biology, geology, and anthropology that demonstrates Darwin's keen powers of observation, written at a time when Western Europeans were exploring and charting the whole world. Although Darwin revisited some areas during the expedition, for clarity the chapters of the book are ordered by reference to places and locations rather than by date.
Darwin's notes made during the voyage include comments hinting at his changing views on the fixity of species. On his return, he wrote the book based on these notes, at a time when he was first developing his theories of evolution through common descent and natural selection. The book includes some suggestions of his ideas, particularly in the second edition of 1845.


== Context ==
In May 1826 two ships left Plymouth to survey the southern coasts of South America. The senior officer of the expedition was Phillip Parker King, Commander and Surveyor of HMS Adventure, and under his orders Pringle Stokes was Commander and Surveyor of HMS Beagle. In August 1828 Stokes died after shooting himself. In December Robert FitzRoy was given command of the ship and continued the survey. In January 1830 FitzRoy noted in his journal the need for expertise in mineralogy or geology, on a future expedition he would "endeavour to carry out a person qualified to examine the land; while the officers, and myself, would attend to hydrography." Both ships returned to Plymouth in August 1830. King was in poor health, and retired from the Navy (he moved back to his home in Australia in 1832).
In August 1831, while Beagle was being readied, FitzRoy's offer of a place for a self-funded naturalist was raised with University of Cambridge professors. Henslow passed it on to Darwin who was well qualified and, enthused by reading Humboldt's Personal Narrative, was on a short study tour with geologist Adam Sedgwick in preparation for a planned visit with friends to Tenerife. Darwin read the letters when he got home, and was eager to join the voyage.']
reference_answer:
The original title of Charles Darwin's book published in 1839 was "Journal and Remarks." This title reflected Darwin's personal account of his experiences during the second survey expedition of HMS Beagle. Due to the popularity of Darwin's narrative, the publisher reissued it later in 1839 under a new title: "Darwin's Journal of Researches."

The book underwent further revisions, and the revised second edition published in 1845 retained this title, "Journal of Researches." Over time, as the work gained recognition and was republished, its title evolved to what is now best known: "The Voyage of the 'Beagle'." This final version appeared in a republication of the book in 1905.

query: Describe the circumstances under which Robert FitzRoy assumed command of HMS Beagle and his subsequent actions regarding scientific expertise on future expeditions.

reference_answer:
Robert FitzRoy assumed command of HMS Beagle in December 1828 following the death of Pringle Stokes, who had been the Commander and Surveyor of the ship. Stokes died after shooting himself, which led to FitzRoy being appointed as his replacement under the senior officer Phillip Parker King.

Upon taking command, FitzRoy recognized the importance of having scientific expertise on board for future expeditions. In January 1830, he noted in his journal the need for a qualified individual who could examine geological and mineralogical aspects while the officers focused on hydrography. This foresight led to his offer of a place for a self-funded naturalist on an upcoming expedition.

In August 1831, as Beagle was being prepared for its voyage, FitzRoy's proposal was communicated to University of Cambridge professors. The offer reached Charles Darwin through Professor Henslow, who recognized Darwin’s qualifications and enthusiasm for such an endeavor. Inspired by Alexander von Humboldt's "Personal Narrative" and his own studies with geologist Adam Sedgwick, Darwin eagerly accepted the opportunity to join the expedition as a naturalist.

This decision was pivotal in shaping the scientific contributions of the voyage, particularly through Darwin's observations that later influenced his theories on evolution. FitzRoy’s initiative to include scientific expertise thus played a crucial role in the success and legacy of HMS Beagle's journey.

query: How did Charles Darwin become involved with the voyage of the HMS Beagle, and what influenced his decision to join?

['The Voyage of the Beagle is the title most commonly given to the book written by Charles Darwin and published in 1839 as his Journal and Remarks, bringing him considerable fame and respect. reference_answer:
Charles Darwin became involved with the voyage of the HMS Beagle through a series of events that began in August 1831. At this time, Captain Robert FitzRoy was preparing for another survey expedition aboard the HMS Beagle. Recognizing the need for expertise in mineralogy or geology on future voyages, FitzRoy offered a place to a self-funded naturalist who could assist with examining the land.

This offer was communicated by FitzRoy's contacts at the University of Cambridge, where professors were approached about finding a suitable candidate. The opportunity was passed along to Professor John Stevens Henslow, who recommended Charles Darwin for the position. Darwin was well qualified due to his background in natural sciences and his enthusiasm for exploration, which had been sparked by reading Alexander von Humboldt's "Personal Narrative."

Darwin was particularly influenced by his recent study tour with geologist Adam Sedgwick, during which they explored geological formations. This experience, combined with his interest in Humboldt’s work, made him eager to join the voyage. Upon receiving letters about the opportunity from Henslow, Darwin quickly expressed his eagerness and enthusiasm to participate in the expedition.

Thus, a combination of FitzRoy's need for scientific expertise on board, recommendations from academic contacts, and Darwin's own passion for natural science and exploration led to his involvement with the HMS Beagle voyage.

query: How did Darwin manage his journal entries while traveling on land, and what challenges did he face with this method?
reference_contexts:
['=== Darwin's diary / journal ===
On board the ship, Darwin began a day-to-day record of activities in the form of a diary, which he commonly called "my Journal". Darwin wrote entries, in ink, while on the ship or when staying for a period in a house on shore. When travelling on land, he left the manuscript on the ship, and made pencil notes in pocket books to record details of his excursions along with his field notes on geology and natural history. He then wrote up his diary entries from these notes or from memory, sometimes several weeks after the event.
Pages 1 and 2, dated 16 December 1831, outline events from Darwin arriving home on 29 August to his arrival at Devonport on 24 October. From page 3 onwards he adopts a consistent layout, with month, the year and place in a heading at the top, page number in a top corner, and the day of the month in the margin at each entry. After delays and false starts due to weather, they set off on 27 December. Darwin suffered seasickness, and his entry for that date starts "I am now on the 5th of Jan.y writing the memoranda of my misery for the last week".
In April, a month after reaching South America, he wrote to his sister Caroline that he was struggling to write letters, partly due to "writing everything in my journal". A few weeks later at Botafogo in Rio de Janeiro, tired and short of time, he sent her "in a packet, my commonplace Journal.— I have taken a fit of disgust with it & want to get it out of my sight, any of you that like may read it.— a great deal is absolutely childish: Remember however this, that it is written solely to make me remember this voyage, & that it is not a record of facts but of my thoughts". He invited criticisms. In reply, his sister Catherine praised his "interesting and entertaining" descriptions,  "Susan read the Journal aloud to Papa, who was interested, and liked it very much". His Wedgwood relatives had asked to see it at Maer Hall. Darwin left that "entirely in your hands.— I suspect the first part is abominaly childish, if so do not send it to Maer.— Also, do not send it by the Coach, (it may appear ridiculous to you) but I would as soon loose a piece of my memory as it.— I feel it is of such consequence to my preserving a just recollection of the different places we visit."
By 14 July 1833 Darwin had sent more of his diary. On 28 October Caroline gave the requested critical assessment – in the first part Darwin had "probably from reading so much of Humboldt, got his phraseology & occasionly made use of the kind of flowery french expressions which he uses, instead of your own simple straight forward & far more agreeable style. I have no doubt you have without perceiving it got to embody your ideas in his poetical language & from his being a foreigner it does not sound unnatural in him". However, "the greatest part I liked exceedingly & could find no fault". In July 1834, Darwin agreed that these points were "perfectly just", and continued to update his diary carefully.
As Beagle headed homewards in April 1836,  Darwin told Caroline that FitzRoy too was busy with writing "the account of the Voyage". This "Book" might be "rather diffuse", but otherwise good: "his style is very simple & excellent. He has proposed to me, to join him in publishing the account, that is, for him to have the disposal & arranging of my journal & to mingle it with his own. Of course I have said I am perfectly willing, if he wants materials; or thinks the chit-chat details of my journal are any ways worth publishing. He has read over the part, I have on board, & likes it." Darwin asked his family about this idea, but would be aware the custom of the Navy was that the captain had a right to first use of papers.']
reference_answer:
While traveling on land during his voyage aboard the HMS Beagle, Charles Darwin managed his journal entries by leaving the main manuscript of his diary on board the ship. Instead, he used pocket books to make pencil notes about his excursions and field observations related to geology and natural history. These notes served as a temporary record that he would later use to write up detailed entries in his journal from memory or based on these notes when back on the ship.

Darwin faced several challenges with this method of managing his journal entries:

1. **Memory Reliance**: Since Darwin wrote up his diary entries from memory or brief pencil notes, there was a risk of forgetting details over time. This reliance on memory could lead to inaccuracies or omissions in his records.

2. **Time Lag**: There were often delays between when he made the initial notes and when he had the opportunity to write them into his journal. These delays sometimes extended to several weeks, which increased the likelihood of forgetting specific details about events or observations.

3. **Volume of Information**: Darwin was collecting a vast amount of information during his travels, making it challenging to capture everything in brief notes that would later be expanded upon in his journal.

4. **Self-Criticism and Discontent**: At times, Darwin expressed dissatisfaction with his own writing style, describing parts of his journal as "childish" or overly influenced by other writers like Humboldt. This self-criticism sometimes led to a temporary loss of interest in maintaining the journal, as he mentioned wanting to get it out of sight.

Despite these challenges, Darwin continued to update and refine his diary carefully, recognizing its importance for preserving his memories of the voyage.

query: What concerns did Darwin express about sharing his journal with others, and how did his family respond to these concerns?
reference_contexts:
['=== Darwin's diary / journal ===
On board the ship, Darwin began a day-to-day record of activities in the form of a diary, which he commonly called "my Journal". Darwin wrote entries, in ink, while on the ship or when staying for a period in a house on shore. When travelling on land, he left the manuscript on the ship, and made pencil notes in pocket books to record details of his excursions along with his field notes on geology and natural history. Darwin suffered seasickness, and his entry for that date starts "I am now on the 5th of Jan.y writing the memoranda of my misery for the last week".

A few weeks later at Botafogo in Rio de Janeiro, tired and short of time, he sent her "in a packet, my commonplace Journal.— I have taken a fit of disgust with it & want to get it out of my sight, any of you that like may read it.— a great deal is absolutely childish: Remember however this, that it is written solely to make me remember this voyage, & that it is not a record of facts but of my thoughts". By 14 July 1833 Darwin had sent more of his diary. On 28 October Caroline gave the requested critical assessment – in the first part Darwin had "probably from reading so much of Humboldt, got his phraseology & occasionly made use of the kind of flowery french expressions which he uses, instead of your own simple straight forward & far more agreeable style. I have no doubt you have without perceiving it got to embody your ideas in his poetical language & from his being a foreigner it does not sound unnatural in him". However, "the greatest part I liked exceedingly & could find no fault". In July 1834, Darwin agreed that these points were "perfectly just", and continued to update his diary carefully.
As Beagle headed homewards in April 1836,  Darwin told Caroline that FitzRoy too was busy with writing "the account of the Voyage". This "Book" might be "rather diffuse", but otherwise good: "his style is very simple & excellent. He has proposed to me, to join him in publishing the account, that is, for him to have the disposal & arranging of my journal & to mingle it with his own. Of course I have said I am perfectly willing, if he wants materials; or thinks the chit-chat details of my journal are any ways worth publishing. He has read over the part, I have on board, & likes it." Darwin asked his family about this idea, but would be aware the custom of the Navy was that the captain had a right to first use of papers.']
reference_answer:
Charles Darwin expressed several concerns regarding sharing his journal with others. Firstly, he was worried that parts of his journal might be perceived as "childish" or overly influenced by the style of Alexander von Humboldt, which included flowery French expressions. He feared this could affect how his work was received and valued. Additionally, Darwin was concerned about preserving the accuracy of his memories regarding the places they visited during the voyage.

Despite these concerns, Darwin's family responded positively to his journal. His sister Catherine found his descriptions "interesting and entertaining," while Susan read it aloud to their father, who also enjoyed it. The Wedgwood relatives expressed interest in seeing the journal at Maer Hall, but Darwin left the decision of sharing it entirely in their hands, particularly advising against sending parts he deemed unsuitable.

Caroline provided a critical assessment, noting that Darwin had adopted Humboldt's phraseology and suggesting he return to his simpler style. However, she also praised most of the content as excellent. Overall, Darwin's family seemed supportive and appreciative of his work, encouraging him to continue updating his diary carefully.

query: Describe the arrangement between Darwin and Captain FitzRoy regarding the publication of their voyage accounts. How did naval customs influence this agreement?
reference_contexts:
['=== Darwin's diary / journal ===
On board the ship, Darwin began a day-to-day record of activities in the form of a diary, which he commonly called "my Journal". Darwin wrote entries, in ink, while on the ship or when staying for a period in a house on shore. He has read over the part, I have on board, & likes it." Darwin asked his family about this idea, but would be aware the custom of the Navy was that the captain had a right to first use of papers.']
reference_answer:
The arrangement between Charles Darwin and Captain Robert FitzRoy concerning the publication of their voyage accounts involved a collaborative effort where FitzRoy proposed that they publish an account together. In this collaboration, FitzRoy would have control over how to arrange and incorporate Darwin's journal entries into the final published work. Darwin agreed to this proposal, indicating his willingness to contribute materials from his journal if FitzRoy deemed them valuable for publication.

Naval customs played a significant role in shaping this agreement. According to these customs, the captain of a naval expedition had the right to first use any papers or documents produced during the voyage. This meant that FitzRoy, as the captain of HMS Beagle, held primary rights over the materials collected and documented by Darwin during their journey. Consequently, Darwin's journal entries could be used at FitzRoy's discretion for his account of the voyage, reflecting the hierarchical structure and customary practices within naval expeditions of that time. This arrangement ensured that FitzRoy had editorial control while allowing Darwin to contribute to a broader narrative about their scientific discoveries and experiences.

query: Who were the individuals that Darwin consulted about publishing his journal, and what was their general opinion on how it should be published?
reference_contexts: ['=== Journal and remarks ===\nSoon after Darwin\'s return, he was at a party hosted by Fanny and Hensleigh Wedgwood for their relatives on 4 December 1836. They agreed to review his journal. The physician and travel writer Henry Holland looked at some pages and "thought that it would not be worth while to publish it alone, as it would be partly going over the same ground with the Captain", leaving Darwin "more perplexed" but "becoming rather inclined to the plan of mixing up long passages with Capt Fitzroy." He would "go on with the geology and let the journal take care of itself", but Emma Wedgwood did not think Holland "any judge as to what is amusing or interesting", and like Catherine thought it should be published by itself, not "mixed up with Capt. FitzRoy\'s". Fanny and Hensleigh found the "Journal so interesting, that it is quite difficult to stop to criticize". Though "not in general a good reader of travels", he "found no part of yours tedious." They had "read a great deal of it aloud too" as a more severe test, and concluded it had "more variety and a greater number of interesting portions" than other travel books, "the less it is mixed up with the Captains the better." \nAfter advice from Broderip, FitzRoy wrote on 30 December that "One volume might be for King—another for you—and a third for me. The profits if any, to be divided into three equal portions—What think you of such a plan?" Darwin agreed, and began work on his volume. In March he told Fox "I am now hard at work and give up every thing else for it. Our plan is as follows.— Capt. FitzRoy writes two volumes, out of the materials collected during both the last voyage under Capt. King to T. del Fuego and during our circumnavigation.— I am to have the third volume, in which I intend giving a kind of journal of a naturalist, not following however always the order of time, but rather the order of position.— The habits of animals will occupy a large portion, sketches of the geology, the appearance of the country, and personal details will make the hodge-podge complete.— Afterwards I shall write an account of the geology in detail, and draw up some Zoological papers.— So that I have plenty of work, for the next year or two, and till that is finished I will have no holidays."']
reference_answer:
Charles Darwin consulted several individuals regarding the publication of his journal. These included:

1. **Henry Holland**: A physician and travel writer who reviewed some pages of Darwin's journal. He suggested that it might not be worthwhile to publish the journal alone, as it would overlap with Captain FitzRoy's accounts. This left Darwin more perplexed.

2. **Emma Wedgwood**: She disagreed with Holland’s assessment, stating he was not a good judge of what is amusing or interesting. Emma supported the idea of publishing the journal by itself rather than mixing it with Captain FitzRoy's work.

3. **Catherine (likely Catherine Darwin)**: Like Emma, she believed that the journal should be published separately and not mixed with Captain FitzRoy’s accounts.

4. **Fanny Wedgwood**: She found the journal very interesting and thought it was difficult to criticize. Fanny agreed with her brother Hensleigh that the journal had more variety and interesting portions than other travel books, suggesting it would be better off not being mixed with Captain FitzRoy's writings.

5. **Hensleigh Wedgwood**: He shared Fanny’s view on the journal's interest and variety, also supporting its separate publication from Captain FitzRoy's accounts.

Overall, while Henry Holland suggested combining Darwin's work with Captain FitzRoy's, Emma Wedgwood, Catherine, Fanny, and Hensleigh Wedgwood all favored publishing Darwin's journal independently.

query: Describe the plan proposed by FitzRoy for dividing the work into volumes and how Darwin intended to structure his own volume.
reference_contexts: ['=== Journal and remarks ===\nSoon after Darwin\'s return, he was at a party hosted by Fanny and Hensleigh Wedgwood for their relatives on 4 December 1836. They agreed to review his journal. The physician and travel writer Henry Holland looked at some pages and "thought that it would not be worth while to publish it alone, as it would be partly going over the same ground with the Captain", leaving Darwin "more perplexed" but "becoming rather inclined to the plan of mixing up long passages with Capt Fitzroy." He would "go on with the geology and let the journal take care of itself", but Emma Wedgwood did not think Holland "any judge as to what is amusing or interesting", and like Catherine thought it should be published by itself, not "mixed up with Capt. FitzRoy\'s". Fanny and Hensleigh found the "Journal so interesting, that it is quite difficult to stop to criticize". Though "not in general a good reader of travels", he "found no part of yours tedious." They had "read a great deal of it aloud too" as a more severe test, and concluded it had "more variety and a greater number of interesting portions" than other travel books, "the less it is mixed up with the Captains the better." \nAfter advice from Broderip, FitzRoy wrote on 30 December that "One volume might be for King—another for you—and a third for me. The profits if any, to be divided into three equal portions—What think you of such a plan?" Darwin agreed, and began work on his volume. In March he told Fox "I am now hard at work and give up every thing else for it. Our plan is as follows.— Capt. FitzRoy writes two volumes, out of the materials collected during both the last voyage under Capt. King to T. del Fuego and during our circumnavigation.— I am to have the third volume, in which I intend giving a kind of journal of a naturalist, not following however always the order of time, but rather the order of position.— The habits of animals will occupy a large portion, sketches of the geology, the appearance of the country, and personal details will make the hodge-podge complete.— Afterwards I shall write an account of the geology in detail, and draw up some Zoological papers.— So that I have plenty of work, for the next year or two, and till that is finished I will have no holidays."']
reference_answer:
FitzRoy proposed a collaborative plan for publishing their experiences from the voyage. The idea was to divide the content into three separate volumes, each authored individually but based on shared materials collected during the voyages under Captain King and FitzRoy's circumnavigation. Specifically:

1. **Volume Division**: 
   - One volume would be dedicated to King.
   - Another volume would be written by FitzRoy himself.
   - The third volume was assigned to Darwin.

2. **Profit Sharing**:
   - Any profits from the publication of these volumes were to be divided equally among the three contributors: King, FitzRoy, and Darwin.

Darwin's approach for his own volume involved a unique structure:

1. **Content Focus**: 
   - Darwin intended to write as if he were keeping a journal of a naturalist.
   
2. **Structure**:
   - Instead of following a strict chronological order, Darwin planned to organize the content based on geographical position or thematic relevance.
   
3. **Key Elements**:
   - A significant portion would be dedicated to the habits of animals.
   - He also intended to include sketches of geology and descriptions of the appearance of various countries visited during the voyage.
   - Personal details and experiences would be interspersed throughout, creating a comprehensive narrative.

4. **Future Work**:
   - After completing this volume, Darwin planned to write in more detail about the geological aspects and prepare some zoological papers, indicating his commitment to extensive work on these subjects for the following year or two.

This plan reflects both FitzRoy's collaborative spirit and Darwin's dedication to thoroughly documenting their scientific observations.

query: What specific aspects of natural history did Darwin plan to focus on in his volume, and what additional works did he intend to produce after completing this project?

reference_answer:
In his planned volume, Charles Darwin intended to focus on several specific aspects of natural history. He aimed to provide a "kind of journal of a naturalist," which would not strictly follow the chronological order but rather be organized by geographical position. Key elements he planned to include were:

1. **Habits of Animals**: A significant portion of his volume was dedicated to exploring and documenting animal behaviors.
2. **Geology**: He intended to incorporate sketches and observations related to geology, providing insights into the geological features encountered during his travels.
3. **Appearance of the Country**: Descriptions of the landscapes and physical characteristics of various regions were also planned.
4. **Personal Details**: Personal anecdotes and experiences would be included to enrich the narrative.

After completing this volume, Darwin had additional projects in mind:

1. **Detailed Account of Geology**: He planned to write a more comprehensive work focusing specifically on geological observations.
2. **Zoological Papers**: Darwin intended to prepare detailed papers on zoological subjects, likely expanding upon the animal habits and species he documented during his travels.

These plans indicate that Darwin was preparing for an extensive period of research and writing following the completion of his initial volume.

query: How did Charles Darwin feel about becoming an author, and what specific event led him to express this sentiment?
reference_contexts:
['== Publication of FitzRoy's narrative and Darwin's book ==
Darwin reorganised his diary, trimmed parts, and incorporated scientific material from his field notes. He passed his writing to the publisher Henry Colburn, and in August 1837 had the first proofs back from the printer. Henslow helped check them; on 4 November, Darwin wrote to him that "If I live till I am eighty years old I shall not cease to marvel at finding myself an author". Part of it was printed, "the smooth paper and clear type has a charming appearance, and I sat the other evening gazing in silent admiration at the first page of my own volume, when I received it from the printers!"
FitzRoy had to edit King's account of the first voyage, adding extracts from the journal of the previous captain of Beagle and his own journal when he took over, as well as write his own account of the second voyage. In mid-November 1837, he took offence that Darwin's preface to volume III (and a similar preface to the first part of The Zoology) lacked, in his view, enough acknowledgement of the help given by FitzRoy and other officers; the problem was overcome. By the end of February 1838, King's Narrative (volumes I) and Darwin's Journal (volume III) had been printed, but FitzRoy was still hard at work on volume II.
The Narrative was completed and published as a four-volume set in May 1839, as the Narrative of the Surveying Voyages of His Majesty's Ships Adventure and Beagle, describing their Examination of the Southern Shores of South America, and the Beagle's Circumnavigation of the Globe, in three volumes. Volume one covers the first voyage under Commander Phillip Parker King, volume two is FitzRoy's account of the second voyage. Darwin's Journal and Remarks, 1832–1835 forms the third volume, and the fourth volume is a lengthy appendix. The publication was reviewed as a whole by Basil Hall in the July 1839 issue of the Edinburgh Review. 
Volume two includes FitzRoy's Remarks with reference to the Deluge in which he recanted his earlier interest in the geological writings of Charles Lyell and his remarks to Darwin during the expedition that sedimentary features they saw "could never have been effected by a forty days' flood", asserting his renewed commitment to a literal reading of the Bible. He had married on the ship's return, and his wife was very religious.
Darwin's contribution proved remarkably popular and the publisher, Henry Colburn of London, announced on 15 August a separate volume of Darwin's text, published with a new title page as Journal of Researches into the Geology and Natural History of the various countries visited by H.M.S. Beagle. The Publishers‘ Circular of 2 September carried an advertisement for this volume, as well as a separate advertisement for the other volumes, as listed at William Broderip's article in the Quarterly Review. This was apparently done without seeking Darwin's permission or paying him a fee.']
reference_answer: Charles Darwin felt surprised and somewhat amazed at finding himself as an author. He expressed this sentiment in a letter to his mentor John Stevens Henslow on November 4, 1837. In the letter, he wrote that "If I live till I am eighty years old I shall not cease to marvel at finding myself an author." This feeling was prompted by receiving the first proofs of his work from the printer and seeing his writing in print for the first time. He described sitting in silent admiration gazing at the first page of his volume, which contributed to his sense of wonder about becoming an author.

It is clear that despite this initial conflict, the work continued, and the Narrative was completed and published as a four-volume set in May 1839.

query: Describe the circumstances under which Darwin's contribution to the Narrative became a separate volume, including any actions taken by the publisher without his consent.
reference_contexts:
['== Publication of FitzRoy's narrative and Darwin's book ==
Darwin reorganised his diary, trimmed parts, and incorporated scientific material from his field notes. He passed his writing to the publisher Henry Colburn, and in August 1837 had the first proofs back from the printer. By the end of February 1838, King's Narrative (volumes I) and Darwin's Journal (volume III) had been printed, but FitzRoy was still hard at work on volume II.
The Narrative was completed and published as a four-volume set in May 1839, as the Narrative of the Surveying Voyages of His Majesty's Ships Adventure and Beagle, describing their Examination of the Southern Shores of South America, and the Beagle's Circumnavigation of the Globe, in three volumes. Volume one covers the first voyage under Commander Phillip Parker King, volume two is FitzRoy's account of the second voyage. Darwin's Journal and Remarks, 1832–1835 forms the third volume, and the fourth volume is a lengthy appendix. The publication was reviewed as a whole by Basil Hall in the July 1839 issue of the Edinburgh Review. 
Volume two includes FitzRoy's Remarks with reference to the Deluge in which he recanted his earlier interest in the geological writings of Charles Lyell and his remarks to Darwin during the expedition that sedimentary features they saw "could never have been effected by a forty days' flood", asserting his renewed commitment to a literal reading of the Bible. He had married on the ship's return, and his wife was very religious.
Darwin's contribution proved remarkably popular and the publisher, Henry Colburn of London, announced on 15 August a separate volume of Darwin's text, published with a new title page as Journal of Researches into the Geology and Natural History of the various countries visited by H.M.S. Beagle. The Publishers‘ Circular of 2 September carried an advertisement for this volume, as well as a separate advertisement for the other volumes, as listed at William Broderip's article in the Quarterly Review. This was apparently done without seeking Darwin's permission or paying him a fee.']
reference_answer:
Darwin's contribution to the "Narrative of the Surveying Voyages" initially formed part of Volume III. However, due to its popularity, the publisher Henry Colburn decided to release Darwin's text as a separate volume. This decision was made without seeking Darwin's permission or compensating him with a fee.

The circumstances leading up to this involved several steps:

1. **Initial Publication**: The full narrative was published in May 1839 as a four-volume set, which included Darwin's "Journal and Remarks" as Volume III.

2. **Popularity of Darwin’s Work**: After the publication, it became evident that Darwin's contribution was particularly well-received by readers.

3. **Publisher's Decision**: Recognizing this popularity, Henry Colburn announced on 15 August 1839 a separate volume specifically for Darwin's text. This new edition was titled "Journal of Researches into the Geology and Natural History of the various countries visited by H.M.S. Beagle."

4. **Actions Without Consent**: The decision to publish Darwin’s work separately, including creating a new title page for this version, was done without consulting Darwin or providing him with any financial compensation.

5. **Advertisements**: This separate volume was advertised in the Publishers’ Circular on 2 September 1839, alongside advertisements for the other volumes of the original narrative set.

This sequence of events highlights how Darwin's work gained independent recognition and commercial success, albeit through actions taken by his publisher without his direct involvement or benefit at that time.

query: What significant changes were made to the title and content of Darwin's work in its second edition published in 1845, and how did these reflect his evolving ideas on evolution?
reference_contexts:
['=== Second edition: changing ideas on evolution ===

The second edition of 1845 incorporated extensive revisions made in the light of interpretation of the field collections and developing ideas on evolution. This edition was commissioned by the publisher John Murray, who actually paid Darwin a fee of £150 for the copyright. The full title was modified to Journal of Researches into the Natural History and Geology of the countries visited during the voyage of H.M.S. Beagle round the world.
In the first edition, Darwin remarks in regard to the similarity of Galápagos wildlife to that on the South American continent, "The circumstance would be explained, according to the views of some authors, by saying that the creative power had acted according to the same law over a wide area". (This was written in a reference to Charles Lyell's ideas of "centres of creation".) Darwin notes the gradations in size of the beaks of species of finches, suspects that species "are confined to different islands", "But there is not space in this work, to enter into this curious subject."
Later editions hint at his new ideas on evolution:

Considering the small size of these islands, we feel the more astonished at the number of their aboriginal beings, and at their confined range... within a period geologically recent the unbroken ocean was here spread out. Hence, both in space and time, we seem to be brought somewhat near to that great fact – that mystery of mysteries – the first appearance of new beings on this earth.
Speaking of the finches with their gradations in size of beaks, he writes "one might really fancy that from an original paucity of birds in this archipelago, one species had been taken and modified for different ends."
In 1890, John Murray published an illustrated edition of the book, at the suggestion of the artist Robert Taylor Pritchett, who was already known for accompanying voyages of the RYS Wanderer and Sunbeam, and producing pictures used in books on these cruises. In his foreword to this edition of Journal and Researches, Murray said that most "of the views given in this work are from sketches made on the spot by Mr. Pritchett, with Mr. Darwin's book by his side", and the illustrations had been "chosen and verified with the utmost care and pains".


== Contents – places Darwin visited ==
For readability, the chapters of the book are arranged geographically rather than in an exact chronological sequence of places Darwin visited or revisited. The main headings (and in some cases subheadings) of each chapter give a good idea of where he went, but not the exact sequence. See second voyage of HMS Beagle for a detailed synopsis of Darwin's travels. The contents list in the book also notes topics discussed in each chapter, not shown here for simplicity. Names and spellings are those used by Darwin. The list below is based on the Journal and Remarks of 1839.

Preface
Chapter I: St. Jago–Cape de Verde Islands (St. Paul's Rocks, Fernando Noronha, 20 Feb.., Bahia, or San Salvador, Brazil, 29 Feb..)
Chapter II: Rio de Janeiro
Chapter III: Maldonado
Chapter IV: Río Negro to Bahia Blanca
Chapter V: Bahía Blanca
Chapter VI: Bahia Blanca to Buenos Aires
Chapter VII: Buenos Aires to St. Fe
Chapter VIII: Banda Oriental
Chapter IX: Patagonia
Chapter X: Santa Cruz–Patagonia
Chapter XI: Tierra del Fuego
Chapter XII: The Falkland Islands
Chapter XIII: Strait of Magellan
Chapter XIV: Central Chile
Chapter XV: Chiloe and Chonos Islands
Chapter XVI: Chiloe and Concepcion
Chapter XVII: Passage of Cordillera
Chapter XVIII: Northern Chile and Peru
Chapter XIX: Galapagos Archipelago
Chapter XX: Tahiti and New Zealand
Chapter XXI: Australia (Van Diemen's Land)
Chapter XXII: Coral Formations (Keeling or Cocos Islands)
Chapter XXIII: Mauritius to England
In the second edition, the Journal of Researches of 1845, chapters VIII and IX were merged into a new chapter VIII on "Banda Oriental and Patagonia", and chapter IX now included "Santa Cruz, Patagonia and The Falkland Islands". After chapter X on Tierra del Fuego, chapter XI had the revised heading "Strait of Magellan–Climate of the Southern Coasts". The following chapters were renumbered accordingly. Chapter XIV was given the revised heading "Chiloe and Concepcion: Great Earthquake", and chapter XX had the heading "Keeling Island:–Coral Formations", with the concluding chapter XXI keeping the heading "Mauritius to England".


== Notes ==']
reference_answer:
In the second edition of Charles Darwin's "Journal of Researches," published in 1845, several significant changes were made both to the title and content that reflected his evolving ideas on evolution.

### Title Changes:
1. **Full Title Modification**: The full title was changed from its original form to "Journal of Researches into the Natural History and Geology of the countries visited during the voyage of H.M.S. Beagle round the world." This change emphasized a broader scope, focusing more explicitly on natural history and geology.

### Content Changes:
1. **Revised Chapters**: 
   - In this edition, chapters VIII and IX from the first edition were merged into a new chapter titled "Banda Oriental and Patagonia."
   - Chapter IX was expanded to include content about "Santa Cruz, Patagonia, and The Falkland Islands."
   - After chapter X on Tierra del Fuego, chapter XI was re-titled as "Strait of Magellan–Climate of the Southern Coasts," reflecting a more detailed exploration of these regions.
   - Chapter XIV's heading was revised to "Chiloe and Concepcion: Great Earthquake," indicating an inclusion or emphasis on significant geological events observed during his travels.

2. **Hints at Evolutionary Ideas**:
   - Darwin began hinting at his developing ideas on evolution, particularly in relation to the wildlife he studied. For example, he noted the gradations in size of finch beaks and suggested that species might have been modified from an original form for different purposes.
   - He expressed astonishment at the number of unique species found on small islands like the Galápagos, suggesting a recent origin of these species due to geological changes. This was a departure from earlier views attributing such phenomena to "centres of creation" as proposed by Charles Lyell.

3. **Illustrations**:
   - The 1890 illustrated edition included sketches made on-site by Robert Taylor Pritchett, which were chosen and verified with care, adding visual context to Darwin's observations and supporting his evolving theories.

These changes in the second edition reflect Darwin's shift from a more descriptive account of his travels to one that begins to incorporate his nascent ideas about evolution, natural selection, and the adaptation of species. The modifications in content and title underscore his growing interest in explaining the diversity of life through geological and biological processes rather than solely attributing it to fixed "centres of creation."

In 1845, he commissioned the second edition of the book, which incorporated extensive revisions reflecting Darwin's developing ideas on evolution. This edition was notable for its expanded title and included insights into evolutionary theory that were not present in the first edition. For his role in commissioning this revised edition, John Murray paid Darwin a fee of £150 for the copyright.

In 1890, John Murray again contributed to the publication history by releasing an illustrated edition of "Journal of Researches." This edition was suggested by Robert Taylor Pritchett, an artist known for accompanying voyages and producing illustrations for books on these cruises. In his foreword to this edition, Murray highlighted that most views in the book were based on sketches made by Pritchett during Darwin's travels, with Darwin's original work as a reference. Murray emphasized that these illustrations had been "chosen and verified with the utmost care and pains," underscoring their authenticity and relevance.

Robert Taylor Pritchett's contribution was primarily through his artistic skills, providing visual representations of the places and subjects described in Darwin's journal. His involvement ensured that the 1890 edition offered readers a more vivid and accurate depiction of Darwin's observations during his voyage on HMS Beagle.

In summary, John Murray facilitated both the textual revisions and the enhanced visual presentation of Darwin's work through these editions, while Robert Taylor Pritchett contributed by providing detailed illustrations that enriched the reader's experience.

query: How were the chapters of Darwin's book reorganized in the second edition, specifically regarding the geographical regions covered by chapters VIII through XI? Provide details on how these changes reflect a restructuring of content.
reference_contexts:
['=== Second edition: changing ideas on evolution ===

The second edition of 1845 incorporated extensive revisions made in the light of interpretation of the field collections and developing ideas on evolution. This edition was commissioned by the publisher John Murray, who actually paid Darwin a fee of £150 for the copyright. The full title was modified to Journal of Researches into the Natural History and Geology of the countries visited during the voyage of H.M.S. Beagle round the world.
In the first edition, Darwin remarks in regard to the similarity of Galápagos wildlife to that on the South American continent, "The circumstance would be explained, according to the views of some authors, by saying that the creative power had acted according to the same law over a wide area". (This was written in a reference to Charles Lyell's ideas of "centres of creation".) Darwin notes the gradations in size of the beaks of species of finches, suspects that species "are confined to different islands", "But there is not space in this work, to enter into this curious subject."
Later editions hint at his new ideas on evolution:

Considering the small size of these islands, we feel the more astonished at the number of their aboriginal beings, and at their confined range... within a period geologically recent the unbroken ocean was here spread out. Hence, both in space and time, we seem to be brought somewhat near to that great fact – that mystery of mysteries – the first appearance of new beings on this earth.
Speaking of the finches with their gradations in size of beaks, he writes "one might really fancy that from an original paucity of birds in this archipelago, one species had been taken and modified for different ends."
In 1890, John Murray published an illustrated edition of the book, at the suggestion of the artist Robert Taylor Pritchett, who was already known for accompanying voyages of the RYS Wanderer and Sunbeam, and producing pictures used in books on these cruises. In his foreword to this edition of Journal and Researches, Murray said that most "of the views given in this work are from sketches made on the spot by Mr. Pritchett, with Mr. Darwin's book by his side", and the illustrations had been "chosen and verified with the utmost care and pains".


== Contents – places Darwin visited ==
For readability, the chapters of the book are arranged geographically rather than in an exact chronological sequence of places Darwin visited or revisited. The main headings (and in some cases subheadings) of each chapter give a good idea of where he went, but not the exact sequence. See second voyage of HMS Beagle for a detailed synopsis of Darwin's travels. The contents list in the book also notes topics discussed in each chapter, not shown here for simplicity. Names and spellings are those used by Darwin. The list below is based on the Journal and Remarks of 1839.

Preface
Chapter I: St. Jago–Cape de Verde Islands (St. Paul's Rocks, Fernando Noronha, 20 Feb.., Bahia, or San Salvador, Brazil, 29 Feb..)
Chapter II: Rio de Janeiro
Chapter III: Maldonado
Chapter IV: Río Negro to Bahia Blanca
Chapter V: Bahía Blanca
Chapter VI: Bahia Blanca to Buenos Aires
Chapter VII: Buenos Aires to St. Fe
Chapter VIII: Banda Oriental
Chapter IX: Patagonia
Chapter X: Santa Cruz–Patagonia
Chapter XI: Tierra del Fuego
Chapter XII: The Falkland Islands
Chapter XIII: Strait of Magellan
Chapter XIV: Central Chile
Chapter XV: Chiloe and Chonos Islands
Chapter XVI: Chiloe and Concepcion
Chapter XVII: Passage of Cordillera
Chapter XVIII: Northern Chile and Peru
Chapter XIX: Galapagos Archipelago
Chapter XX: Tahiti and New Zealand
Chapter XXI: Australia (Van Diemen's Land)
Chapter XXII: Coral Formations (Keeling or Cocos Islands)
Chapter XXIII: Mauritius to England
In the second edition, the Journal of Researches of 1845, chapters VIII and IX were merged into a new chapter VIII on "Banda Oriental and Patagonia", and chapter IX now included "Santa Cruz, Patagonia and The Falkland Islands". After chapter X on Tierra del Fuego, chapter XI had the revised heading "Strait of Magellan–Climate of the Southern Coasts". The following chapters were renumbered accordingly. Chapter XIV was given the revised heading "Chiloe and Concepcion: Great Earthquake", and chapter XX had the heading "Keeling Island:–Coral Formations", with the concluding chapter XXI keeping the heading "Mauritius to England".


== Notes ==']
reference_answer:
In the second edition of Charles Darwin's "Journal of Researches" (1845), there were specific changes to the organization and headings of certain chapters, particularly those covering geographical regions from chapters VIII through XI. Here are the details on how these chapters were reorganized:

1. **Chapters VIII and IX Merged**: In the first edition, Chapter VIII was titled "Banda Oriental," and Chapter IX covered "Patagonia." In the second edition, these two chapters were merged into a single chapter VIII with the new title "Banda Oriental and Patagonia." This restructuring reflects an effort to consolidate related geographical content under one heading.

2. **Inclusion of Additional Regions**: The newly combined Chapter VIII also included information on "Santa Cruz" and "The Falkland Islands," which were originally covered in separate chapters (Chapter IX for Santa Cruz, and Chapter XII for the Falkland Islands) in the first edition. This indicates a reorganization to provide a more comprehensive overview of these interconnected regions within one chapter.

3. **Revised Heading for Chapter XI**: In the second edition, after Chapter X on "Tierra del Fuego," Chapter XI was given the revised heading "Strait of Magellan–Climate of the Southern Coasts." This change reflects an expansion or refinement in content to include additional thematic elements such as climate alongside geographical descriptions.

4. **Renumbering of Subsequent Chapters**: Due to these changes, chapters that followed were renumbered accordingly. For example, what was Chapter IX in the first edition became Chapter X in the second edition, and so on for subsequent chapters.

These modifications reflect a restructuring aimed at providing a more integrated narrative of Darwin's observations across related geographical regions, possibly to enhance coherence or thematic focus within the text.

query: Who was the first recipient of the Copley Medal, and what were they recognized for?
reference_contexts:
['The Copley Medal is the most prestigious award of the Royal Society of the United Kingdom, conferred "for sustained, outstanding achievements in any field of science". The award alternates between the physical sciences or mathematics and the biological sciences. It is arguably the highest British and Commonwealth award for scientific achievement, and has often been included among the most distinguished international scientific awards.
Given annually, the medal is the oldest Royal Society medal awarded and the oldest surviving scientific award in the world, having first been given in 1731 to Stephen Gray, for "his new Electrical Experiments: – as an encouragement to him for the readiness he has always shown in obliging the Society with his discoveries and improvements in this part of Natural Knowledge". The medal is made of silver-gilt and awarded with a £25,000 prize.
It is awarded to "senior scientists" irrespective of nationality, and nominations are considered over three nomination cycles. Since 2022, scientific teams or research groups are collectively eligible to receive the medal; that year, the research team which developed the Oxford–AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine became the first collective recipient. John Theophilus Desaguliers has won the medal the most often, winning three times, in 1734, 1736 and 1741. In 1976, Dorothy Hodgkin became the first female recipient; Jocelyn Bell Burnell, in 2021, became the second.


== History ==
In 1709, Sir Godfrey Copley, the MP for Thirsk, bequeathed Abraham Hill and Hans Sloane £100 (roughly equivalent to £17,156 in 2023) to be held in trust for the Royal Society "for improving natural knowledge to be laid out in experiments or otherwise for the benefit thereof as they shall direct and appoint". After the legacy had been received the following year, the interest of £5 was duly used to provide recurring grants for experimental work to researchers associated with the Royal Society, provided they registered their research within a stipulated period and demonstrated their experiments at an annual meeting. In 1726, following a proposal by Sloane, the grants were extended to "strangers" unaffiliated with the Society to encourage "new and useful experiments," though it was only five years later that Stephen Gray became the first such recipient. Prior to Gray, John Theophilus Desaguliers was apparently the only recipient of the grant, but had not always conducted the required annual demonstration.
In November 1736, Martin Folkes, then vice-president of the Society, suggested the Copley grant be converted to "a medal or other honorary prize to be bestowed on the person whose experiment should be best approved...a laudable emulation might be excited among men of genius to try their invention, who in all probability may never be moved for the sake of lucre". On 7 December 1736, the Council of the Royal Society agreed to Folkes' proposal, passing a resolution that the annual Copley grant of five pounds (roughly equivalent to £986 in 2023) be converted to a gold medal "of the same Value, with the Arms of the Society impress’d on it," to be gifted "for the best Experiment produced within the Year, and bestowed in such a manner as to avoid any Envy or Disgust in Rivalship". John Belchier was the first to receive the new award in 1737; due to delays in approving a medal design, however, the medal, designed and struck by John Sigismund Tanner of the Royal Mint, was only presented to Belchier in 1742. Gray and Desaguliers received their medals retrospectively.
Into the early 19th century, medal recipients were selected by the President of the Royal Society, though not always on the basis of publications and experimental demonstrations; political and social connections were also key considerations, along with service in the general interests of the Society. During the long presidency of Joseph Banks, the medal was frequently awarded to recipients whose researches were of a practical or technical nature, involving improvements to scientific equipment or instrument design. In 1831, new regulations adopted by the Royal Society Council made the medal an annual award, dropped the requirement for conducting the qualifying research within a certain period and officially opened it to scientists from any nation; although the medal had previously been awarded to foreign scientists including Alessandro Volta, the majority of recipients had been British subjects. A second donation of £1666 13s. 4d. (roughly equivalent to £212,366 in 2023) was made by Sir Joseph William Copley in 1881, and the interest from that amount is used to pay for the medal.']
reference_answer: The first recipient of the Copley Medal was Stephen Gray. He received it in 1731 for his "new Electrical Experiments." The award served as an encouragement for his readiness to share his discoveries and improvements in this area of natural knowledge with the Royal Society. This recognition marked the beginning of what is now considered the oldest surviving scientific award in the world.

Prior to Gray, John Theophilus Desaguliers was apparently the only recipient of the grant, but had not always conducted the required annual demonstration.
In November 1736, Martin Folkes, then vice-president of the Society, suggested the Copley grant be converted to "a medal or other honorary prize to be bestowed on the person whose experiment should be best approved...a laudable emulation might be excited among men of genius to try their invention, who in all probability may never be moved for the sake of lucre". On 7 December 1736, the Council of the Royal Society agreed to Folkes' proposal, passing a resolution that the annual Copley grant of five pounds (roughly equivalent to £986 in 2023) be converted to a gold medal "of the same Value, with the Arms of the Society impress’d on it," to be gifted "for the best Experiment produced within the Year, and bestowed in such a manner as to avoid any Envy or Disgust in Rivalship". John Belchier was the first to receive the new award in 1737; due to delays in approving a medal design, however, the medal, designed and struck by John Sigismund Tanner of the Royal Mint, was only presented to Belchier in 1742. Gray and Desaguliers received their medals retrospectively.
Into the early 19th century, medal recipients were selected by the President of the Royal Society, though not always on the basis of publications and experimental demonstrations; political and social connections were also key considerations, along with service in the general interests of the Society. During the long presidency of Joseph Banks, the medal was frequently awarded to recipients whose researches were of a practical or technical nature, involving improvements to scientific equipment or instrument design. In 1831, new regulations adopted by the Royal Society Council made the medal an annual award, dropped the requirement for conducting the qualifying research within a certain period and officially opened it to scientists from any nation; although the medal had previously been awarded to foreign scientists including Alessandro Volta, the majority of recipients had been British subjects. A second donation of £1666 13s. 4d. (roughly equivalent to £212,366 in 2023) was made by Sir Joseph William Copley in 1881, and the interest from that amount is used to pay for the medal.']
reference_answer: The Royal Society Council agreed to convert the annual Copley grant into a gold medal in November 1736. The medal was designed and struck by John Sigismund Tanner of the Royal Mint.

query: What significant change regarding eligibility for the Copley Medal occurred in 1831?
reference_contexts:
['The Copley Medal is the most prestigious award of the Royal Society of the United Kingdom, conferred "for sustained, outstanding achievements in any field of science". The award alternates between the physical sciences or mathematics and the biological sciences. It is arguably the highest British and Commonwealth award for scientific achievement, and has often been included among the most distinguished international scientific awards.
Given annually, the medal is the oldest Royal Society medal awarded and the oldest surviving scientific award in the world, having first been given in 1731 to Stephen Gray, for "his new Electrical Experiments: – as an encouragement to him for the readiness he has always shown in obliging the Society with his discoveries and improvements in this part of Natural Knowledge". The medal is made of silver-gilt and awarded with a £25,000 prize.
It is awarded to "senior scientists" irrespective of nationality, and nominations are considered over three nomination cycles. Since 2022, scientific teams or research groups are collectively eligible to receive the medal; that year, the research team which developed the Oxford–AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine became the first collective recipient. John Theophilus Desaguliers has won the medal the most often, winning three times, in 1734, 1736 and 1741. In 1976, Dorothy Hodgkin became the first female recipient; Jocelyn Bell Burnell, in 2021, became the second.


== History ==
In 1709, Sir Godfrey Copley, the MP for Thirsk, bequeathed Abraham Hill and Hans Sloane £100 (roughly equivalent to £17,156 in 2023) to be held in trust for the Royal Society "for improving natural knowledge to be laid out in experiments or otherwise for the benefit thereof as they shall direct and appoint". After the legacy had been received the following year, the interest of £5 was duly used to provide recurring grants for experimental work to researchers associated with the Royal Society, provided they registered their research within a stipulated period and demonstrated their experiments at an annual meeting. In 1726, following a proposal by Sloane, the grants were extended to "strangers" unaffiliated with the Society to encourage "new and useful experiments," though it was only five years later that Stephen Gray became the first such recipient. Prior to Gray, John Theophilus Desaguliers was apparently the only recipient of the grant, but had not always conducted the required annual demonstration.
In November 1736, Martin Folkes, then vice-president of the Society, suggested the Copley grant be converted to "a medal or other honorary prize to be bestowed on the person whose experiment should be best approved...a laudable emulation might be excited among men of genius to try their invention, who in all probability may never be moved for the sake of lucre". On 7 December 1736, the Council of the Royal Society agreed to Folkes' proposal, passing a resolution that the annual Copley grant of five pounds (roughly equivalent to £986 in 2023) be converted to a gold medal "of the same Value, with the Arms of the Society impress’d on it," to be gifted "for the best Experiment produced within the Year, and bestowed in such a manner as to avoid any Envy or Disgust in Rivalship". John Belchier was the first to receive the new award in 1737; due to delays in approving a medal design, however, the medal, designed and struck by John Sigismund Tanner of the Royal Mint, was only presented to Belchier in 1742. Gray and Desaguliers received their medals retrospectively.
Into the early 19th century, medal recipients were selected by the President of the Royal Society, though not always on the basis of publications and experimental demonstrations; political and social connections were also key considerations, along with service in the general interests of the Society. During the long presidency of Joseph Banks, the medal was frequently awarded to recipients whose researches were of a practical or technical nature, involving improvements to scientific equipment or instrument design. In 1831, new regulations adopted by the Royal Society Council made the medal an annual award, dropped the requirement for conducting the qualifying research within a certain period and officially opened it to scientists from any nation; although the medal had previously been awarded to foreign scientists including Alessandro Volta, the majority of recipients had been British subjects. A second donation of £1666 13s. 4d. (roughly equivalent to £212,366 in 2023) was made by Sir Joseph William Copley in 1881, and the interest from that amount is used to pay for the medal.']
reference_answer: In 1831, a significant change regarding the eligibility for the Copley Medal was that new regulations adopted by the Royal Society Council made the medal an annual award and officially opened it to scientists from any nation. This change removed the previous requirement that qualifying research had to be conducted within a certain period and allowed foreign scientists to receive the medal more formally, although some non-British recipients had already been awarded prior to this regulation.

query: How did George Airy describe the distinction of the Copley Medal in 1850, and what does this suggest about its international recognition at that time?
reference_contexts:
['== Prestige of the medal ==
By the 1840s, the Copley Medal had achieved international prestige; in 1850, George Airy noted the distinction of the medal was that it was "offered to the competition of the world." The Copley medal has been characterised as a predecessor to the Nobel Prize. Since its inception, it has been awarded to many distinguished scientists, including 52 winners of the Nobel Prize: 17 in Physics, 21 in Physiology or Medicine, and 14 in Chemistry.


== Medal recipients ==


== See also ==
List of biology awards
List of chemistry awards
List of geology awards
List of mathematics awards
List of physics awards


== References ==


== External links ==

"Royal Society: Copley Medal". Royal Society. 30 November 2023. Archived from the original on 6 September 2015. Retrieved 24 May 2016.']
reference_answer: In 1850, George Airy described the distinction of the Copley Medal as being "offered to the competition of the world." This description suggests that by that time, the medal had achieved significant international prestige and was recognized globally. The fact that it was open to worldwide competition indicates its status as a highly esteemed award in the scientific community, comparable to modern prestigious awards like the Nobel Prize. This global recognition underscores the Copley Medal's importance and influence in promoting excellence in science across different countries and disciplines.

query: In what ways has the Copley Medal been characterized as a predecessor to another prestigious award, and how many Nobel Prize winners have also received it?

reference_answer:
The Copley Medal has been characterized as a predecessor to the Nobel Prize due to its international prestige and recognition in the scientific community. By the 1840s, it was noted for being "offered to the competition of the world," highlighting its global significance. This level of distinction aligns with the criteria and reputation associated with the Nobel Prizes.

Furthermore, since its inception, the Copley Medal has been awarded to many distinguished scientists, including a significant number who have also won Nobel Prizes. Specifically, 52 Nobel Prize winners have received the Copley Medal: 17 in Physics, 21 in Physiology or Medicine, and 14 in Chemistry. This overlap underscores the medal's role as an early indicator of scientific excellence that is later recognized by the Nobel Committee.
